context.speaker: Martha Boston
context.text: That's right but that's goes to the question, the substantive standards aren't in question here the only issue –

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: No, I suggest though that what is in question is the burden of proof, I mean that's the what does a constitution require by a way of burden of proof and my suggestion and my question is that there maybe no one answer applicable to 50 different states because each State has different criteria for involuntary commitment.

context.speaker: Martha Boston
context.text: I understand.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Are there not some states where the statute provides precisely what Mr. Justice Stewart has just outlined that a commitment involuntarily maybe made on the testimony of two physicians?

context.speaker: Martha Boston
context.text: I'm not aware of there being any states that don't require other criteria.

context.speaker: Martha Boston
context.text: I'm not aware of any states that will allow commitment based just upon mental illness, to mental illness plus something and it maybe cast in terms of welfare and protection as Texas is.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well in many states, well they may have a hearing they don't have a jury trial.

context.speaker: Martha Boston
context.text: That's true, but that's a very different analysis.

context.speaker: Martha Boston
context.text: This court has considered the issue of a jury trial or right to counsel separately through the situations in which it's considered the standard of proof.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Ms Boston may I ask you a question, it's somewhat similar to Justice Stewart's question.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Suppose you had statute that required proof beyond a reasonable doubt of three facts, one mental illness, two some past act of violence and thirdly say that in that commitment would be in the best interest of the patient.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: I assume that would be a perfectly constitutionally statute in your view, if those were the three substantive requirements?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I am not the Court, I am the one that–

context.speaker: James Hury
context.text: I beg your pardon sir.

context.speaker: James Hury

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.text: Mrs. Gordon, why do you think you need to assert the idea that private schools do not have as part of their mission the training for citizenship.

context.text: You don't have to defend the statute of New York on the ground that it's perfect or that it's perfectly consistent.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: People would have the private school who wants private schools just as we have religious schools.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But as Justice Stevens suggested there are certain minimum requirements that are common to all of those?

context.speaker: Judith A. Gordon
context.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There are no constitutional requirements that state statutes have to be internally consistent, is there?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But the rule does not apply except in public schools to the extent that the rule applies it applies in the governmental monopoly.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: I'm simply trying to suggest a distinction between all of the previous cases and this one which is based on the function of the job regardless of whether the state --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: How about private security police?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I mean, obviously, they're not state official but nonetheless they prefer the same functions as police, isn't that kind of analogous what Justice Stevens is talking about?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It is somewhat analogous, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: I don't know exactly where the political community exception established by this Court is going to lead in the future.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: All I'm suggesting is that to date it is only been applied by this Court to cases involving pure governmental monopolies and I think that's an appropriate place to draw the line and not to extend it further than that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Do you think first statute does just that as Mr. Justice Stevens suggest it applies only to the governmental monopoly or the public schools of the limited category, public primary and not higher education?

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: Your Honor, the point I'm trying to make is that the Court should focused on the actual function involved.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: Of course, we could have private security police but the function of teaching is not a governmental monopoly.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 1810, Arizona Public Service Company against Snead will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This is a direct appeal from the Supreme Court of New Mexico, this number is 77-1810.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The case involves the validity of a New Mexico tax imposed upon the privilege of generating electricity.

Arizona Public Service Company v. Snead.speaker: Justice Stewart
Arizona Public Service Company v. Snead.case_name: Arizona Public Service Company v. Snead
Arizona Public Service Company v. Snead.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 18, 1979

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The New Mexico Supreme Court upheld the validity of this energy tax against federal statutory and constitutional attacks and the issues have been brought to this Court by way of a direct appeal under Section 1257(2) of Title 28 of the United States Code.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The appellants contend that the New Mexico tax is invalid under a specific federal statute as well as under the Commerce, Due Process, and Import-Export Clauses of the constitution.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reason set out in the Court's written opinion, we conclude that under the Supremacy Clause, the tax is invalid by reason of the federal statute, and accordingly, we reversed the judgment without reaching the substantive constitutional issues.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment in which he has been joined by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Although, perhaps the person that you were -- had probable cause to arrest was thought to be fleeing a suspect and has no connection with the suitcase?

context.speaker: Joseph H. Purvis
context.text: I certainly think you can and I think that that situation, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, is extremely analogous to the situation in Chambers where the officers had probable cause to believe that that vehicle contained four men who fit the description of the robbers of a store, and that was the reason that they stopped.

context.speaker: Joseph H. Purvis
context.text: And, once given that valid auto exception search, I think or -- it allowed them or deemed reasonable the search of the entire vehicle.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: May I be sure I understand your answer to Mr. Justice White's hypothetical about a truck containing a piano.

context.speaker: Joseph H. Purvis
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Do you take the position that that would authorize a search of the glove compartment?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The taxicab is a common carrier, is it not?

context.speaker: Jack T. Lassiter
context.text: Yes, it is.

context.speaker: Jack T. Lassiter
context.text: I think --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let me pursue that by saying, to take the illustration, the hypothetical Justice White posed, about the highjacked truck which has stolen a piano and the driver is part of that operation.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There, you have not a common carrier but a private car.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would you say that you could search the glove compartment as well as searching the back of the car to see if the piano was there?

context.text: Secondly, there's a caution in the Broadrick opinion that if the statute needs to be interpreted by the State Court, then the overbreadth doctrine should be --

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: I understand.

context.text: Isn't that enough as I think it was implicit in Justice Stevens' questions, if it forbids you from speaking and you make the good faith of assertion that I want to speak this way and I can't unless I -- do I have to violate the statute in order to make a --?

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: It would be easier to answer that question I submit Mr. Justice White --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: All the defendant have to say, all the Attorney General of the state have to say, well I never attempted to apply it to him, they only have to say to avoid the case --

context.speaker: Jerome Cohen
context.text: They are not required to provide us with anything.

context.speaker: Jerome Cohen
context.text: They don't even have to give us a name, a list of the names and addresses of the employees and in a migrant situation, it will be very important for us to at least under the NLRA, for example, (Inaudible) rule gives us the name and address of the employees seven days after an election.

context.speaker: Jerome Cohen
context.text: What this statute says is you can only get the names of the employees ten days after the election.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Cohen, I'm just following up on Mr. Justice Rehnquist's question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing you just repeal the statute, would there be any, be any obligation on the part of the employer to give you any of that information or that access?

context.speaker: Jerome Cohen
context.text: I think in that case you would be able to engage, there would be a general trespass law that would apply, you would be able to engage in a general case-by-case analysis as to whether there was no -- whether there was or was not alternate means of communicating with the workers.

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: That is the Rule 65 rule, so that Carroll in effect in a First Amendment case affirmed the Rule 65 approach to life.

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: There is nothing in this appendix, nothing or anywhere in the record that indicates that in fact there was any impropriety, any failure to observe the Rule 65 or any failure to attempt, there is simply nothing on it as to what the facts in those cases were.

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: This is just not the case to be deciding the constitutionality of Rule 65, which is necessarily what you have to decide.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The problem as I understand the burden of Mr. Justice White's question is how does the Supreme Court of the state really get to construe the statue in this?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, it's on the book, it does have some deterrent effect I suppose on the First Amendment --

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: I would think that in a case in which I go into court, I get a TRO against Mr. Cohen, and then he immediately goes before the Arizona Supreme Court on a special writ, which that statute provides and attempts to dissolve it because I've violated his constitutional rights.

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: I'm advised by my colleague Mr. Dailey that where in fact it is determined that the race was affected by drugging and then it is within the power of the Racing and Wagering Board to take back the purse.

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: However, the pari-mutuel results aren't affected because of the immediate pay off of on the pari-mutuel bets.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I think you may have been overbroad.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: At least I should think you were in responding to Mr. Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: If it was demonstrated affirmatively that the owner and not the trainer had drugged the horse and that the owner had done this without the trainer's knowledge then surely, the trainer would not be punished, would he?

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: Yes, in fact I made that point to Mr. Justice Stevens that this relates where in fact it is found that a third person -- a third party or an outsider whether it would be from another owner --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So the suspension in effect was issued by the Commission here?

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: It was issued by an authorized agent of the Commission subject to review at the request of the licensee by the full Commission or full Board.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I'm not sure you completed your answer to Justice White.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Precisely, what section of the regulations authorized the suspension?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think you started to tell us.

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: I think it would be clear from the examination of the New York statutes.

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: It would be Article 56 of the New York civil practice law and rules relating to the jurisdiction of the New York Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: I think Cohen and Karger powers of the New York Court of Appeals which is somewhat dated but it is the definitive treaties would also make this clear that just as a denial of certiorari is not the --

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. General Hammer, would it be true that the decision of the appellate division of the New York Supreme Court was consistent with Mr. Justice Powell's understanding of New York law or suggested understanding?

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: I would have to disagree because in our view, a drugged horse situation would automatically qualify as a ground for summary suspension of a licensee.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Do you think those are absorbed in the Constitution?

context.speaker: Phylis Skloot Bamberger
context.text: I don't think that they are absorbed into the Constitution, but I suggest to the Court that they are valid evidence which can be considered, expert evidence from, in the case of the government drafted standards it's own correctional officials, which would indicate what they believe to be adequate and I think that is evidence which the district court considered and which is appropriate to consider in making an evaluation.

context.speaker: Phylis Skloot Bamberger
context.text: It's the same ways in the medical case, doctor's assertions are not constitutional principles, but they are valid evidence in determining what is the proper legal standard to apply.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Ms. Bamberger if you are finished responding to Mr. Justice Rehnquist I would like to ask a question.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: You emphasized privacy, does that mean that you would take the same position if the room were, say the size of ordinary double room in a small town hotel with twin beds.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Do you object to the fact that two people in the same room?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But this one which deserves some exploration, would you not agree?

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: Well, we would be prepared if the Court wants us to research the question and submit our views on it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: No we'll pass on that later.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We'll resume -- excuse me, we'll resume arguments at 1 o'clock, but subject to Mr. Justice White's question.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Yes, you won't be back at 1 o'clock?

Board of Governors of Federal Reserve Sy.speaker: Justice Burger

Board of Governors of Federal Reserve Sy.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 11, 1978

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Board of Governors of Federal Reserve System against First Lincolnwood Corporation will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The issue is whether the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 allows the Federal Reserve Board to deny approval of certain transactions that would not weaken the financial condition of a holding company or a subsidiary bank but would produce a financially unsound bank holding company.

Board of Governors of Federal Reserve Sy.speaker: Justice Marshall
Board of Governors of Federal Reserve Sy.case_name: Board of Governors of Federal Reserve System v. First Lincolnwood Corporation
Board of Governors of Federal Reserve Sy.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 11, 1978

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Board's exercise of its authority to prevent the formation of financially unsound bank holding company has had significant and beneficial effects on the banking system.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The effects of which Congress has been appraised and although Congress has amended the statute, it has not sought to curtail the Board's authority.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We see no basis for this Court to act where Congress has not.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.speaker: Justice Stevens
Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.case_name: Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 15, 1979

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I stand corrected.

context.speaker: Alan J. Hruska
context.text: Yeah.

context.speaker: Alan J. Hruska
context.text: I was up to the point Your Honor was I was positing the situation of major oil companies conspiring to fix prices to their 50 largest customers and suggesting that the 50 first customer would plainly have a right to obtain an injunction against that price fix because the conspiracy would obviously pollute the market in which their customers are attempting to buy, so that if CBS would drop its ASCAP market license and attempt to bypass and ASCAP, CBS, like the 51st customer of oil, would certainly have the right to enjoin the price fixing that was still going on directly in sales to ABC and NBC, even though CBS has stopped dealing with the cartel.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Again and Mr. Justice Rehnquist asked you if the analogy really is fair, the 50 oil companies do not sell anything that no one company could sell, but in this case, the government particularly stresses the point that ASCAP sells a product that no one composer could sell, namely the blanket license and that the blanket license has independent economic utility. How do you respond to that?

context.speaker: Alan J. Hruska
context.text: Absent conspiracy, Twentieth Century Fox cannot market the films made by MGM and United Artists and Columbia Pictures and all the other motion picture companies, but that is not excuse for price fixing, that is a definition of price fixing.

context.speaker: Alan J. Hruska
context.text: Now, the department's point is literally based on several “benefits” that the department believes it perceives in this situation and those benefits are illusory.

Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.speaker: Justice Burger
Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.case_name: Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 17, 1979

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgments and opinion of the Court in 1578, Broadcast Music Incorporated against Columbia Broadcasting and the consolidated case will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This litigation involves challenges under the antitrust laws to some of the business practices of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers called ASCAP, and Broadcast Music, Inc. referred to as BMI.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: These two organizations act as clearinghouses for their member or affiliated composers, writers or publishers whom copyrights on musical compositions.

Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.speaker: Justice White
Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.case_name: Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Broadcast Music, Inc. v. Columbia Broadc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 17, 1979

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed holding that the blanket-license did indeed constitute a per se violation of Section 1 of the Sherman Act.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We granted the petition for certiorari filed by ASCAP and BMI and I have now filed an opinion in which we hold in disagreement with the Court of Appeals that the blanket-license is not illegal per se under the Sherman Act and remanding the case to the Court of Appeals to consider any further issues that may be appropriate in that court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Eight justices, that is seven other justices and myself, concur in the opinion in which we have filed and which states at some length the reasons for our conclusions.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion, while agreeing with us that the blanket-license is not illegal per se, he would affirm that judgment of the Court of Appeals on the ground that the challenge licensing practice when tested under the rule of reason is an unreasonable restraint of trade.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This is an issue which the majority opinion does not reach and which may be open in the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordingly reversed.

context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion, while agreeing with us that the blanket-license is not illegal per se, he would affirm that judgment of the Court of Appeals on the ground that the challenge licensing practice when tested under the rule of reason is an unreasonable restraint of trade.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This is an issue which the majority opinion does not reach and which may be open in the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordingly reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Alex Stephen Keller
context.text: I'm not familiar with the common law of the other 49 states and therefore I can't tell you whether all of the elements required in Colorado are to in all of this --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And why do you -- why do you agree so readily that it has to be that -- that Bankruptcy Act contemplates a national standard of fraud rather than picking up the fraud standard from the state in which the bankruptcy court is sitting or picking up the fraud standard of any state -- of the -- of any state law which might govern the country -- or the transaction?

context.speaker: Alex Stephen Keller
context.text: The reason I say that and I could --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The -- Mr. Justice -- that's the case that Mr. Justice Stevens announce this morning seem to think that the state law wouldn't govern it and it might the state law might be different in every state.

context.speaker: Alex Stephen Keller
context.text: Well, I couldn't -- of course it would be entirely in error.

context.speaker: Alex Stephen Keller
context.text: But the way I read the --

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Oh, you did not include -- you did not charge Mr. Felsen with misrepresentation?

context.speaker: Alex Stephen Keller
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Alex Stephen Keller
context.text: No cross-claim against Mr. Felsen did he urge fraud and counsel for petitioner just a few minutes ago conceded that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, I thought it's just as Mr. Justice Powell did that's in the answer?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There was just a statement that he was induced the sign such a guarantee by representations in non-disclosures of material facts by other defendants.

context.speaker: Alex Stephen Keller
context.text: It's not --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What is the general due process?

context.speaker: Max Renea Hicks
context.text: Well, by that I meant the Fourteenth Amendment due process question.

context.speaker: Max Renea Hicks
context.text: This Court has held in numerous kinds of cases that the only things in the Due Process Clause are not rights incorporated from the first 10 amendments, first 8 amendments.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: To pursue Mr. Justice Rehnquist's hypothetical, under this kind of an ordinance the really only safe way that is -- this can avoid embarrassment at least is to carry some form of identification on him at all times, isn't that true?

context.speaker: Max Renea Hicks
context.text: I don't think that's so.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You don't think so?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, if he assumed that -- if he assumed the reason then one of the constitutionality passed on he didn't present the lawfulness of the stop.

context.speaker: Max Renea Hicks
context.text: That's my argument.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Can I just ask you a question on that?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: He did ask the question as Mr. Justice Powell pointed out.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The only thing he wanted to do was stop him and ask him his name and the officer said, "Correct".

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's on page 28 and he says the same thing again a couple of pages later.

context.speaker: Jack Peebles
context.text: Not in -- we do not know what happened in the jury room in this case Your Honor.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: So you're not suggesting any hypothesis about that processes about that.

context.speaker: Jack Peebles
context.text: We are – we're not suggesting any hypotheses.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: No, on that point that you were discussing with Mr. Justice White, when I was in law school it was common for the lecturer to say that divided court opinion carries more weight than a unanimous opinion of a multi judge court whether it was three under the part of appeals or nine here because that showed that the contest -- the issue was contested right -- to the end of the line.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: How do you square that with the sociological studies I suppose -- that each of them has about the same value perhaps.

context.speaker: Jack Peebles
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Burch against Louisiana will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Louisiana Constitution and Code of Criminal Procedure provide that nonpetty criminal cases shall be tried before a jury of six-persons, five of whom must concur to render a verdict.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We granted certiorari in this particular case to decide whether conviction by a nonunanimous six-person jury in a state criminal trial for a nonpetty offense, as contemplated by provisions of the Louisiana law violates the right of an accused to trial by jury guaranteed by the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We don’t pretend to see a bright line below which the number of jurors participating in the trial or verdict would not permit the jury to function the manner required by our prior cases but it is inevitable that lines must be drawn somewhere if the substance of the jury trial right is to be preserved.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We believe that conviction by unanimous six-person juries sufficiently threatens the substance of the jury trial rights so as to violate the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States constitution.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And we therefore reverse Burch’s conviction.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part in which Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall has joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We believe that conviction by unanimous six-person juries sufficiently threatens the substance of the jury trial rights so as to violate the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States constitution.

context.speaker: Ralph C. Ferrara
context.text: Section 36A prescribes breaches of fiduciary duty based upon--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Breach of fiduciary duty.

context.speaker: Ralph C. Ferrara
context.text: Well, the statute doesn’t say what a breach of fiduciary duty it is, but the Congress and both the House and the Senate reports when they passed that Statute said what they thought it met.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, I think -- I don’t still don’t think you have answered Mr. Justice Stevens that where is a -- what specifically in the Statue forbids or forbids a settlement unless you go through this ritual.

context.speaker: Ralph C. Ferrara
context.text: Let me, let me try once again.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Because you know there is a question, just how specific must a Federal law be and in Cort against Ash the court said and I’m for sure you must be quite familiar with that statement in Cort against Ash that --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: -- that except where Federal law expressly requires certain responsibilities and directives with respect to it the state law will govern internal affairs of corporation.

context.speaker: Ralph C. Ferrara
context.text: You have raised two questions.

context.speaker: Ralph C. Ferrara
context.text: Let me try to respond to your first question which is also Mr. Justice Stevens' question.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: You can respond to Justice Stevens' question first.

context.speaker: Ralph C. Ferrara
context.text: Alright.

context.speaker: Ralph C. Ferrara
context.text: First the Investment Company Act clearly defines the composition of a Board of Directors, 40% must be disinterested.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Number 1410, Buttner against the United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The petitioner in this case held a mortgage in North Carolina real estate owned by a corporation that became bankrupt.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Rent was collected after the bankruptcy and before the property was sold.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: First, the Congress of the United States has not enacted any statute governing this question and therefore, there is no federal rule that can be easily applied.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Second, it is primarily the responsibility of the state governments rather than the federal governments to fashion rules of property law.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And therefore, even though this case arises out of a federal bankruptcy proceeding, we hold that the law of North Carolina should be applied for -- essentially, these reasons which are stated in more detail in the opinion filed with the clerk yesterday, the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Caban against Mohammed will be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on appeal for the New York Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: At issue is the constitutionality of New York adoption statute.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In an opinion filed today with the clerk, we hold that the New York statute is in invalid under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: At this with respect to children as old as appellants and where an established relationship exists, the New York statute bears no substantial relation to any important state interest.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly we reversed the Court of Appeals of New York.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in two consolidated cases, Califano against Aznavorian and Aznavorian against Califano will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: These are cross-appeals from the United States District Court for the Southern District of California.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In 1972, Congress enacted the Supplemental Security Income program to aid the needy who are aged, blind, or disabled.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The primary issue in these cases is whether as the District Court held, this restriction is constitutionally impermissible burden on the asserted right of international travel.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in the Court's written opinion filed today, we hold that this provision of the law does not violate the constitution.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the District Court is reversed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Brennan have filed a statement concurring in the result.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The primary issue in these cases is whether as the District Court held, this restriction is constitutionally impermissible burden on the asserted right of international travel.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in the Court's written opinion filed today, we hold that this provision of the law does not violate the constitution.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Brennan have filed a statement concurring in the result.

context.speaker: Herbert Semmel
context.text: But we would submit that, not only isn't there any empirical evidence, but that the statutory history shows that Congress never had that in mind at all.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But would have been relevant in the District Court, would it not?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You say this isn't just simply a denial of a benefit you're appealing from or you might well be precluded by one of the preclusion section.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: If you're challenging the constitutionality of a provision, I would think that sort of evidence that you and Justice Stevens had your colloquy about would have been admissible.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: At least, you would have to make some effort to show that Congress was quite irrational and then ever having thought what the Government suggests a thought about it.

context.speaker: Herbert Semmel
context.text: Well, I think there two answers to that.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mrs. Shapiro, I am somewhat puzzled by your concession that intent makes any difference.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me, Congress knew what it was doing in all these cases.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And if the test were phrased in terms of mothers of illegitimate children, the mother no longer living with the wage earner, but not having lived with the wage earner at the time of his death.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seemed to me there would be the same probability and it just may be what Mr. Justice White was implying, the same probability that the wage earner was not supporting that particular mother because you really have the same set up whether you describe her as a mother of an illegitimate child or as a person who's not a wife.

context.speaker: Harriet S. Shapiro
context.text: Well, the problem is if it's the intent to discriminate or whether it simply a disparate effect of the use of a perfectly proper method of distinguishing between people who are likely to have been supported and people who weren't.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, it's always an intent to discriminate if you say that class A gets benefits and class B doesn't get benefits.

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.text: No sir -- and Title IX sir because --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But I gather -- your comments to the extent they address Title VI disagree with Mr. Justice Stevens' conclusions in Bakke?

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I see.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Lest you must (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: Yes, I think it was wrong.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Of course you do.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And you think Mr. Justice White's concurring opinion had the better of it.

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: I think so.

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: I think that --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Are you suggesting that there is some sort of constitutional right that favors you because “academic freedom” is involved?

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: No sir, I really don't.

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: I'm picking up the point that was made repeatedly in Bakke by -- with great concern.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: By Justice Powell's opinion.

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: By Justice Powell and I believe by Justice Blackmun Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Bernstein, I'm a little puzzled by the argument.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, Mr. Bernstein --

context.speaker: Stuart Bernstein
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: -- I took your reference.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We've been making you skitter all over the lot here but going back to that colloquy that Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I took your suggestion about policy to mean that the legislative history you we're discussing earlier and which is reproduced in the briefs here indicates that as a matter of policy, Congress did not grant a private cause of action.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: This is the policy we're talking about.

Chapman v. Houston Welfare Rights Org..speaker: Justice Marshall
Chapman v. Houston Welfare Rights Org..case_name: Chapman v. Houston Welfare Rights Org.

context.speaker: Jeffrey J. Skarda
context.text: They would not include for example just whether or not somebody was in capacity they did not for AFDC because there would no conflict between state and federal law.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Can you conceive of a case between G1eneral Ferguson, General Motors and General Electric under the Supremacy Clause under 1343(4)?

context.speaker: Jeffrey J. Skarda
context.text: By itself without 1983 then since it would not color of state law problem.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: My answer to Justice White was Supremacy 1343 automatically, you don't really mean that do you?

context.speaker: Jeffrey J. Skarda
context.text: We think we need Section 1983 in the color of state law provisions Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Jeffrey J. Skarda
context.text: No, we think the Sisson 1983 case is present case --

context.speaker: Barbara B. Babcock
context.text: That is my argument.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But General Babcock, I thought you had said perhaps I misunderstood you that in their hearing that the agency would conduct that the Exemption 4 would have to be taken into consideration in deciding whether or not to release.

context.speaker: Barbara B. Babcock
context.text: It would be taken -- in practical terms it would be taken into account in the balancing that is --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But how is that consistent with your answer to Mr. Justice Stewart’s question?

context.speaker: Barbara B. Babcock
context.text: It is that -- as a matter of statutory construction, once it is decided that material falls within the act, then the act does not -- it falls within one of the exemptions, then the act does not apply.

context.speaker: Barbara B. Babcock
context.text: However when the agency then goes on to say, should we release this material?

context.speaker: Burt Braverman
context.text: Yes, yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So that, what was purported to be on the part of Congress an Act setting a floor under disclosure by the agency in your view set a ceiling and at least once.

context.speaker: Burt Braverman
context.text: It continued to recognize practice.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What was Justice White’s question was that did the Freedom of Information Act change the previous practice.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: It locked up -- did the Freedom of Information Act lock up something that was available before or not?

context.speaker: Burt Braverman
context.text: The information as a practice.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 922, Chrysler Corporation against Brown will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The petitioner in this case Chrysler Corporation has numerous contracts with the government.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: One of the conditions of those contracts is that to provide reports and statistical information to specific government agencies in order to show that it is not discriminating in employment on the basis of race or sex and is making acceptable affirmative action efforts.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We agree with both courts below that exemptions to the Freedom of Information Act do not require agencies to withhold information within the terms of these exemptions.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But we conclude that the right regulations involved in this case are substantively and procedurally inadequate to provide the “authorization by law” required by Section 1905.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Court of Appeals was therefore wrong in thinking that the regulations took the requested material out from under the provisions of Section 1905.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Although the Court's opinion today is unanimous, Mr. Justice Marshall has also filed a separate concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But we conclude that the right regulations involved in this case are substantively and procedurally inadequate to provide the “authorization by law” required by Section 1905.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Court of Appeals was therefore wrong in thinking that the regulations took the requested material out from under the provisions of Section 1905.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Although the Court's opinion today is unanimous, Mr. Justice Marshall has also filed a separate concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, that's true.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: I think one of really great things about the field of the municipal government, and I've been in since 1937 as every city's different when you come right down to it.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: You can't say that one city is precisely like another, I don't care how you go about it and how you describe it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But isn't there are common denominator in terms of having them exercise as Mr. Justice Stewart suggested both executive and legislative functions?

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: That's the common denominator of the commission --

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: Have the commission form, yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, that takes to be back to my Government.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The rightful welcome is the mayor who made the assignment of the places.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: So there are as you pointed out all variations but I join Mr. Justice White in asking whether your case would be the same without a please contest standing for a place.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: Well, I think that on reconsideration I would stay with this thing.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: I think that the election at-large is the important thing here and it is true though that there is a tremendous battle about the qualifications of the various commissioners because I too Mr. Justice Brennan grew up and my father run in, that's too long ago I don't remember how many candidate but this was county and not city in selecting this --

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: Not particularly I think that which you have here is a legal conclusion rather than a fact because what did the court do?

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: In a voting rights case you've got to find some barrier, some obstacle.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: Now in Mobile, you have full access, full participation by blacks.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Yes, bur Mr. Justice Stevens points out that the district courts as you may have complete access until the voters get into the voting booths and then there's voting on the basis of color and no black has ever been elected.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: Well, --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, let's just assume that's so.

context.speaker: Charles S. Rhyne
context.text: I didn't quite understand you Mr. Justice.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In New York, the communist got elected ever time.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In Cincinnati I got elected.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You know, I thought in working on this case really, one of the most interesting things was the footnote that Mr. Justice White wrote in Whitcomb versus Chavis where he pointed out that a white man won in a black ward, and a black man won a in a white ward, and I hope that I have lived to see the day where that is America because if you start carving up cities just because you got to guarantee black sits on the governing board, you're going to have to carve out in almost of this.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Blacksher.

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

context.speaker: James P. Turner
context.text: If this -- that the school board have the standard power --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Except for the White against Regester, Whitcomb against Chavis are cases have dealt with the one man, one person, one vote concept which hasn't no basis on the attack here, isn't it?

context.speaker: James P. Turner
context.text: That's -- that's correct Mr. Justice.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would you think anyone would have a complaint pursuant to Mr. Justice Stewart's point more fully with this hypothetical?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The governor, the lieutenant governor, the attorney general being regarded as three of the most important positions in the state government surely, all the elected at-large as they are I suppose everywhere where they are elected, doesn't it produce the same impact in the statewide situation?

context.speaker: James P. Turner
context.text: Well, I've -- I would argue not Mr. Chief Justice the --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Of the appendix and what is the middle paragraph?

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: Yes, the middle paragraph, the last two paragraphs, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Allen, I suppose your answer to a question Mr. Justice Black asked in the other case might be somewhat different in the one that was given.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I think you've taken -- you take that there is a difference between this case and the other case, or maybe you don't.

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: In what respect Your Honor?

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: If we are talking about the intent of the people who operate the statute then we've got what I suppose would be a Yick Wo versus Hopkins type of -- of case in -- in which case we would shift our gaze to the -- and scrutiny to the actions of the -- of the people who were actually operating the election system.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. --

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: And not --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Blacksher, forgive me if I've interrupted your answer to Justice Stevens' question.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I wasn't sure whether you were finished or not.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: If -- if you're right that the judgment should be affirmed here because blacks are not being permitted to have their impact felt in the electoral -- in the electoral process, how far out can that process be -- line of reasoning be extended under your theory?

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: I was responding to Justice Rehnquist in this vein, we have understood --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: (Voice Overlap) and that was a Fourteenth Amendment case?

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: It was and we rely on the Fourteenth Amendment as well as the Fifteenth Amendment and the Voting Rights Act.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But what -- what result do you get in reliance on the amendments you've recited to Justice Stewart and the statutes in respect to -- my question is to who, other than blacks can make this same claim that although they're allowed to vote there are -- they are -- their representation is diluted because of the way of the district -- the districting goes, even though one man, one vote is complied with?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I take it from your referral to Yick Wo that Asian Americans could rely on it.

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: We certainly believe they could, if they can show that they've been treated the way the black folks have been treated in Mobile.

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: There -- there was plenty of evidence in the record to show that there was not polarization of electoral processes along religious lines or along ethnic lines in Mobile, Alabama.

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: That the only discernible polarization from a social standpoint was along the lines of race.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Blacksher, if we just for the moment confine ourselves to the Fourteenth Amendment again, I understand your separate argument on the Voting Rights Act and the Fifteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I'd like to pursue the thought Mr. Justice Rehnquist and I suggested earlier about -- you would say the same theory would apply to Catholics, a -- or religious or an ethnic group as well as to blacks.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: What about a political group such as Republicans?

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: I was asked that -- that question I believe at the first argument, Justice Stevens, and my reply would be the same.

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- government of a municipality, did they?

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: But the principle of White --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That's -- isn't that an issue, one of the issues here suggested by Mr. Justice Rehnquist's concurring opinion in Wise against Lipscomb?

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: J. U. Blacksher
context.text: We wouldn't --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: -- at least -- at least either -- either on -- on the merits or at least put the issue aside?

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: I think -- I think it would be fair to put the -- the issue aside.

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: I think it would also be fair, I mean, I happen to believe on the merits that -- that the Voting Acts -- Voting Act meaning issue is not -- is not a difficult one and that -- that it does come down to meaning the same thing as whatever Your Honors think the Fifteenth Amendment means.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Is -- is your act -- is your response to Justice White's question predicated in -- in any way on an assumption that there is or is not a private cause of action under --

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: I believe, if he asked me to make that assumption.

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: That is the first obstacle --

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: We think -- we believe that that -- that is the beginning point of analysis.

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: The problem arises, somebody gets to exercise and brings a lawsuit when he -- when he sees an at-large system of elections and what can be termed racial -- racially polarized or block voting.

context.speaker: William H. Allen
context.text: The inquiry proceeds from that point, the inquiry proceeds from that point, it doesn't end there, and we -- our concern here is that the -- that we think the District Court essentially ended its inquiry there.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Allen, let's proceed one step further beside -- beyond the assumptions Mr. Justice White made.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Assume the record does demonstrate there's an appropriate finding of a present intent to maintain the system in order to prevent black participation in the school board.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Would that constitute a constitutional violation when the original rule was lawful when adopted?What is your view on that?

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: Now, I -- I say that without meaning to signal any lack of confidence in our argument that there is a private cause of action, but again as a procedural matter the Court has practices which would be applicable to the -- to dealing with it.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now, wait a minute.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I -- I don't understand what you're saying.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: First of all, I didn't understand the reference to me.I think it was intended to be referenced to Justice White but that's neither here nor there in the Bakke case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: What -- what I don't understand here is -- is what you've just told us about the -- whether or not the private right of action under Title II, Section 2 exists.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: As I understand it, the District Court in this case didn't rest at all on the statute.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment of the Court in No. 1844, City of Mobile, Alabama against Bolden will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.text: This case is here on appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The City of Mobile, Alabama has since 1911 been governed by a city commission consisting of three members elected by the voters of the city at large.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The City of Mobile, Alabama has since 1911 been governed by a city commission consisting of three members elected by the voters of the city at large.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The question in this case is whether this at large system of municipal elections violates the rights of Mobile's Negro voters in contravention of federal statutory or constitutional law as held by the District Court and the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons expressed in an opinion filed today, the Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and I have concluded that Mobile's electoral and governmental system does not on the record in this case violate the United States constitution or federal law.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 77-891, Colautti, the Secretary of Welfare of Pennsylvania against Franklin will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, this appeal comes to us from the United States District Court for the Eastern District Court of Pennsylvania.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It is still yet another in the series of cases relating to state regulation of abortion procedures.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The present suit was instituted by the appellees, a licensed physician and certain organizations against Pennsylvania officials challenging the statute on constitutional grounds.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: A three-judge Federal District Court among other things held that Section 5 (a) was unconstitutionally vague.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed with the clerk today, we reaffirm that ruling and hold that the viability determination requirement is void for vagueness and that the standard of care provision is likewise impermissibly vague.

context.text: We'll hear arguments first this morning in Number 610, Columbus Board of Education against Penick.

context.speaker: Samuel H. Porter
context.text: The -- this Court discussed it as a starting point for the fashioning of a remedy and we have no problem with that.

context.speaker: Samuel H. Porter
context.text: What we say is that you can't get to the scope of the remedy until you determine what the magnitude of the wrong is and you can't supply the wrong or its magnitude simply by the statement that it is a dual system or that it's system-wide.

context.speaker: Samuel H. Porter
context.text: That is our position and I might say that, in studying the lower court's opinions, one has to very careful because it's obvious after a reading or two or a thought, that segregation is related in -- to a high degree within those opinions to racial imbalance and the two we would suggest are not the same but they're treated to a high degree the same.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Porter, along the lines of Justice Stevens' question, on page 73 of the appendix to your petition which has Judge Duncan's opinion in it, he says the finding of liability in this case concerns the Columbus school district as a whole.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Actions and omissions by public officials which tend to make black schools black are necessarily have the reciprocal effect of making white schools whiter.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Number 1553, County of Los Angeles against Davis will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The District Court for the Central District of California determined in 1973 that certain hiring practices in the County of Los Angeles respecting the County Fire Department violated 42 United States Code Section 1981.

County of Los Angeles v. Davis.speaker: Justice Brennan
County of Los Angeles v. Davis.case_name: County of Los Angeles v. Davis
County of Los Angeles v. Davis.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 27, 1979

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded the clause for further consideration.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We granted certiorari to consider questions presented as to whether the use of arbitrary employment criteria racially exclusionary in operation, but not purposefully discriminatory, violates 42 U.S.C. 1981, and if so, whether the imposition of minimum hiring quotas for fully qualified minority applicants is an appropriate remedy in this employment discrimination case. Unfortunately, we can't reach those questions.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We now find that the controversy has become moot during the pendency of this litigation. Accordingly, we vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals and direct that court to modify its remand as to direct the District Court to dismiss the action.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell also dissents and has also filed a dissenting opinion in which the Chief Justice joins.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.text: We conclude first that Congress in Title III granted Court's the power in certain circumstances to authorize surreptitious entries for the purpose of installing electronic surveillance equipment.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Yes, but you just made reference to a number of cases in this area whether the courts had gone in your favor.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: So, there is some litigation.

context.speaker: Sana F. Shtasel
context.text: There's extensive litigation in the area.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Doesn't some of your answer to Mr. Justice Blackmun cut the other way in the sense that although the statute is on the books the general kind of hortatory statute, Congress is quite carefully considered whether it wanted to make its members subject to say Title VI, the way the Executive Branch members are or whether it wanted to subject its members to any particular strictures in their hiring and firing and they simply have not done it.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They've considered it and rejected it.

context.speaker: Sana F. Shtasel
context.text: Our argument Mr. Chief Justice -- Mr. Justice Rehnquist, pardon me, is that Congress cannot mandate no remedy for violations of constitutional rights and indeed in this case it is never suggested that there should be no juridical remedy for this kind of violation.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They've considered it and rejected it.

context.speaker: Sana F. Shtasel
context.text: Our argument Mr. Chief Justice -- Mr. Justice Rehnquist, pardon me, is that Congress cannot mandate no remedy for violations of constitutional rights and indeed in this case it is never suggested that there should be no juridical remedy for this kind of violation.

context.speaker: Sana F. Shtasel
context.text: Indeed, it has not brought congressional employees under the ambit of Title VII and it could certainly enact legislation which would so provide and indeed even protect its own members from the possibility of personal liability which has been done in other context.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, that proposition may be entirely some but it doesn't seem to me that it's really makes your case a stronger one than Bivens as you suggested to Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Sana F. Shtasel
context.text: In Bivens, there was no congressional policy stated in the area.

context.speaker: Sana F. Shtasel
context.text: In this one, in this case, at most we have a congressional hortatory statute which declares what the policy of the United States is to be.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You were saying that you know you can't have a right without a remedy in that sort of thing, how about the case of Pacific Telephone and Telegraph versus, I think it was, Fuller decided about 1910 where this Court said that although the constitution does say every state shall be guaranteed to republican form of government nonetheless, the people on Oregon who were challenging the referendum provision were told that cause of action -- that provision simply isn't judicially enforceable.

context.speaker: Sana F. Shtasel
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist, I confess it's not a case that I'm familiar with and can't speculate upon it on those facts but I would suggest that in the context of the Bill of Rights guarantee that Bivens would be the law of the case at this moment in time.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Certainly, Bivens is a lot later than that one.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Ms. Shtasel let me add some variation, hypothetical; it's a variation of Mr. Justice Powell's question.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I don't know how many legislative assistants the president has but let's assume he has five of them and they are all men, and he calls one of the five in and says now you're doing splendid work, I have no complaints at all but in this modern day we've got to have a woman at least one woman and the legislative relations with Congress and therefore I'm sorry but I have to replace you with a woman.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Cause of action?

context.speaker: A. Richard Gear
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The important being is the women?

context.speaker: A. Richard Gear
context.text: That's true sir but we feel that if cause of action is -- excuse me sir?

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Even this precisely one of the arguments that Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Blackmun made in dissent in Bivens.

context.speaker: A. Richard Gear
context.text: That's correct Your Honor.

context.speaker: A. Richard Gear
context.text: We feel that the flood of new lawsuits upon federal issues will inhibit federal action and also inhibit federal employment.

context.speaker: A. Richard Gear
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The important being is the women?

context.speaker: A. Richard Gear

context.text: We feel that the flood of new lawsuits upon federal issues will inhibit federal action and also inhibit federal employment.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I suggest that’s not really what’s involved?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well it may -- that’s what the Supreme Court held though?

context.speaker: Charles M. Oberly, III
context.text: I submit that what -- that the test that the Supreme Court applied is a wrong interpretation of what the requirement of the Fourth Amendment is.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Of course, you could as Justice Brennan suggested, carry out your policy, serve both the state's and the Fourth Amendment by saying that any evidence that comes from such a stop isn’t admissible.

context.speaker: Charles M. Oberly, III
context.text: As to other crimes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well -- but logically, no evidence even of a -- not having a driver’s license or not having a registration would be admissible either, if this is a Fourth Amendment violation.

context.speaker: Charles M. Oberly, III
context.text: I believe he knew that from his prior experience, prior arrest.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well why do we have them dogs specially trained to smell marijuana if they are police who can smell it?

context.speaker: Charles M. Oberly, III
context.text: Your Honor, the answer to that is that the situations involving dogs involves suitcases, luggages where it’s not burned and the animals are able to ascertain a smell that human wouldn’t be able to ascertain.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Oberly you mentioned the hundreds of people would be inconvenienced by the suggestion Mr. Justice Powell made.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Does the record tell us how often these random stops are made, are there hundreds of people stopped or is it -- and if they are not is this -- how can you be sure this is more effective than the other way?

context.speaker: Charles M. Oberly, III
context.text: Referring to hundreds of people I am referring to the possibility of a road block which would have stopped some through fair and line cars up. I am presupposing it would have stopped hundreds.

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: The ultimate result of this rule would be that that could not be used.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Could not be used.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Lukoff, just stopping and asking for a driver’s license, how would they find a man in the trunk.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well that Mr. Justice Stevens is the entire point.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The state is asking here for the mere opportunity to seize the vehicle for a moment as they state for checking license and registration.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let me add a fact, the victim hearing some conversation makes enough noise in the back of the trunk, so that the suspicions and the policemen are excited and aroused.

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: He doesn’t need that Mr. Chief Justice, but the difficulty is that how do we check as to whether he in fact is doing it.

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: Again, it’s arbitrary.

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: If he -- all he says as I stop the tenth car, we don’t know it wasn’t the 11th or the 9th.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, your response to Mr. Justice White indicates that it wouldn’t make any difference for your case and the position you’re taking whether the State legislature had authorized the Attorney General to promulgate rules, guidelines and he promulgated them and said the officers may do thus and so, you’d still make the same points?

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice that presents a slightly different problem.

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: There are different legal issues that maybe involved.

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: The Court, I don’t believe could fashion a rule that said it’s okay in the day time, but not at nighttime, we are not asking, we’re suggesting.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What if Officer Vena had testified that he made stops only between sunrise and sunset because he realized it was kind of a hairy experience for somebody to have the whirling red-light pull-up behind him at night, would you think your case is any weaker?

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: No, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: What is your position as to Mr. Justice Powell’s suggestion of random checkpoint stops?

context.speaker: David M. Lukoff
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun, the position of the defendant is that the random checkpoint stops which the State of Delaware specifically did not reach in the lower opinion or as this Court has held less intrusive in terms of the both subjective and the objective intrusiveness I believe that was held in Martinez --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And so, what’s your position, that’s what I asked?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Number 1571, Delaware against Prouse will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The facts were simple.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The office seized the materials and Prouse was convicted based on this evidence.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Supreme Court of Delaware set aside the conviction on the grounds that the stop of the car without probable cause or reasonable suspicion to believe that some crime was being committed violated the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution and that the evidence which was a product of that illegal stop was less than admissible in evidence with the purpose of convicting Brother Prouse.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The conviction was set aside and the State of Delaware challenges that holding in this Court, but for the reasons which we state in opinion, we have filed today, we agreed with the Delaware Supreme Court that this stop violated the Fourth Amendment and we consequently affirmed this judgment.
