context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: Another potent consideration on the issue of relevancy in my opinion is the fact that the arbitrator himself concluded that a review of the tests would prove nothing and that the Union's case was in no way damaged by lack of access to the test.

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: Of course this Court has on many occasions held that arbitration is the preferred method of solving labor relations disputes.

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: That was done in this case and it was done without the necessity of production of the test.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. McGuinn, just to follow up on Justice Stewart's question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing there have been no arbitration at all, and the Union just made a demand out of the blue for possible future use in connection with possible arbitration, would you have an 8 (a) (5) obligation to comply?

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: Without an actual case or controversy in other words?

Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.speaker: Justice Stevens
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.case_name: Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor Relations Board
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1978

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I'm just -- just have a little trouble identifying what the standard of reference is in which we're supposed to judge the case by.

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: Well, that's an interesting point whether an academic inquiry that comes in out of the blue, we would like to see XYZ material concerning your testing program whether that would lead to an 8 (a) (5) kind of an answer.

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: I tend to -- this company believes in disclosing as much as possible to the employees and I think that the answer to your question for this company would be, yes we would be happy to disclose the validation study.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, then I think I'm asking for a clarification of your answer to Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Was your answer predicated on a relationship to the arbitrator?

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: Yes.

Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.speaker: Justice Burger
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.case_name: Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor Relations Board
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1978

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: And the reason for this is that we concede that the testing program does affect wages and other conditions of employment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That wasn't my question.

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: Maybe if you could repeat your question.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, an hour has elapsed, let Mr. Justice White try it again.

context.speaker: John A. McGuinn
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, suppose in an election, in a Union election campaign, the employer threatens some workers, “if you vote, I'll fire you or something”.

Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.speaker: Justice Burger
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.case_name: Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor Relations Board
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 05, 1979

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 968, Detroit Edison Company against the National Labor Relations Board will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by reason of the grant of a writ of certiorari to United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The duty to bargain collectively imposed upon an employer by Section 8 (a) (5) of the National Labor Relations Act includes a duty to provide relevant information needed by a labor union for the proper performance of its duties as the employees bargaining representative.

Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.speaker: Justice Stewart
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.case_name: Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor Relations Board
Detroit Edison Company v. National Labor.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 05, 1979

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The underlying question in this case is whether the Board's order enforced without modification by the Court of Appeals adequately accommodated these concerns.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons stated in the written opinion of the Court filed with the clerk this morning, we hold that the Board's order did not adequately accommodate these interests.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is vacated and the case is remanded to that court for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion which Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And Mr. Justice Stevens has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

Director, Office of Workers' Compensatio.speaker: Justice Burger
Director, Office of Workers' Compensatio.case_name: Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs v. Rasmussen
Director, Office of Workers' Compensatio.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 21, 1979

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgments and opinion of the Court in Number 1465 and 1491, Director of the Office of Workers' Compensation against Rasmussen will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: With all respect, Mr. William Rasmussen was fatally injured during the course of his employment in South Vietnam when the vehicle in which he was driving was blown up by a land mine.

Director, Office of Workers' Compensatio.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Director, Office of Workers' Compensatio.case_name: Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs v. Rasmussen
Director, Office of Workers' Compensatio.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 21, 1979

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Rasmussen's employer, its insurance carrier, and the Director of the Department of Labors Office of Workers’ Compensation programs, petitioners here contended the death benefits payable to the respondent were limited to $167 a week under another section of the Act.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The administrative law judge and the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit disagreed with the petitioner's contention holding that the death benefits payable under the Act are not subject to the maximum limitations placed on disability payments by this other section of the Act.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Today we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals because of the complex nature of the question, our decision does not lend itself to detailed explanation from the bench, suffice it to say, they were convinced by the plain language of the provisions in the Act and by the legislative history that Congresses omission of a maximum limitation on death benefits payable under the Act was intentional.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these consolidated cases.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist uses --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Jesse W. Walters
context.text: No sir, if I understood Mr. Justice Renhquist's inquiry, it would not be a rule pertaining to a standard practice --.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But that would be issue, wouldn't it?

context.speaker: Jesse W. Walters
context.text: But it would be a rule pertaining as to whether or not that man was paid --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, that's what Justice Stewart's asking you?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Would such a rule be a standard practice --

context.speaker: Jesse W. Walters
context.text: No sir, not in my judgment.

Dougherty County Board of Education v. W.speaker: Justice Burger
Dougherty County Board of Education v. W.case_name: Dougherty County Board of Education v. White
Dougherty County Board of Education v. W.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - NOVEMBER 28, 1978

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Dougherty County, Georgia, Board of Education against White will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on appeal from a three-judge District Court for the Middle District of Georgia.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And the issue is whether a county Board of education in a state covered by Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act must seek federal approval of a rule requiring its employees to take unpaid leaves of absence while they campaign for elective office.

Dougherty County Board of Education v. W.speaker: Justice Marshall
Dougherty County Board of Education v. W.case_name: Dougherty County Board of Education v. White
Dougherty County Board of Education v. W.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - NOVEMBER 28, 1978

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In our dissenting today, we do not intimate any conclusion on the ultimate question which the Attorney General or the District of Columbia District Court will face our submission of the rule for preclearance, that is, whether the rule in fact has a discriminatory purpose or effect.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Rather, we hold only that because Rule 58 has a potential from such discrimination it must be submitted for approval.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The judgment of the District Court is therefore affirmed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has filed a dissenting opinion in which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart dissents for the reasons expressed in Part I of that dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.speaker: Justice Burger
Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.case_name: Douglas Oil Company of California v. Petrol Stops Northwest
Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 18, 1979

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has two opinions in the Court to announce.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The first of these, 77-1547, Douglas Oil against Petrol Stops is a case here on certiorari from the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: It involves a question as to when and by whom transcripts of the grand jury investigation maybe made available to parties in a collateral civil proceedings.

Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.speaker: Justice Powell
Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.case_name: Douglas Oil Company of California v. Petrol Stops Northwest
Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 18, 1979

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: As we think the Arizona court conducting the civil proceedings was in a better position than the Los Angeles court to determine the relevancy and need for the transcripts.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: It was error for the latter court to have ordered that delivery.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: As this order was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, we now reverse that decision. Our reasons are set forth in the court's opinion filed today with the clerk.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens had dissented in an opinion in which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Stewart have joined.

Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.speaker: Justice Powell
Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.case_name: Douglas Oil Company of California v. Petrol Stops Northwest
Douglas Oil Company of California v. Pet.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 18, 1979

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: It was error for the latter court to have ordered that delivery.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: As this order was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, we now reverse that decision. Our reasons are set forth in the court's opinion filed today with the clerk.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.text: It was error for the latter court to have ordered that delivery.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well but suppose the --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But then don't you have -- its your problem?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: You have the show of a problem.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: As Justice Stevens says suppose the victim is somewhat fugacious as the number of these -- rather the suspect is.He isn't going to show up regularly at any one place.

context.speaker: Melvin Bessler
context.text: Well I'm trying to ask you a specific question.

context.speaker: Melvin Bessler
context.text: My own opinion is that the courts, the New York courts would have more trouble with -- for a lineup because you have a live witness than when you can't have a lineup because there's no live witness.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: He would save himself public obloquy.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: He would save himself many inconveniences but the fact that he is not left in the same position when he's compelled to testify as he would have been had that claim --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Frey, could I interrupt you for a moment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Are you speaking in response to Justice Stewart's question of the privilege of a defendant and a criminal case not to take the stand?

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: No, I'm speaking of the privilege of a witness to --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, I understood --

context.speaker: Nanette Laughrey
context.text: This however is not in the record before this Court and we submit that it should not be considered by this Court since it was not considered by the Missouri Supreme Court in making of their decision.

context.speaker: Nanette Laughrey
context.text: Even however, if you do consider that evidence, there is still no explanation for the diminution of the amount of women from 29% to 15% because we submit that if a woman has a right to check the questionnaire and say, "I don't want to serve" and she doesn't then we can assume that she's later when she's called to serve going to say, “Well, the only reason I'm not interested in serving it's because I am a woman.”

context.speaker: Nanette Laughrey
context.text: And there is no proof in the record here as to why women were excused for cause by the judge as evidenced in the tables which are in the appendix.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Ms. Laughrey, let me get back for a moment if I may to your comment about the outmoded stereotype in response to Justice Stevens' question.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Actually, a jury -- lawyers who pick juries operate largely on stereotypes, don't they?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In the sense that, you know people of certain nationalities are believed to award higher personal injury verdicts than others.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 77-6067, Duren against Missouri will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri to review a judgment of that Court affirming a -- the conviction of petitioner, Duren, for first-degree murder.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Under the Missouri law, women are eligible for jury duty and are subject to call, but they are -- but they are entitled to an automatic exemption upon their request, no similar excuse is available to men.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Duren claims that his Sixth and Fourteenth Amendment right to a trial by a jury representing a fair cross-section of the community is violated by the scheme.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Missouri Supreme Court rejected the -- the submission, we reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: As we explain in an opinion on file with the clerk, this case is ruled by Taylor against Louisiana and decided a few terms ago and under that case and under the constitution the Missouri selection scheme is invalid, and hence, we reversed the judgments of Missouri Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Missouri Supreme Court rejected the -- the submission, we reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: As we explain in an opinion on file with the clerk, this case is ruled by Taylor against Louisiana and decided a few terms ago and under that case and under the constitution the Missouri selection scheme is invalid, and hence, we reversed the judgments of Missouri Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Mark Alan Hart
context.text: But there may be occasions when it will be to the suspect's advantage to talk particularly if he had a good alibi and the lawyer --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Wasn't that said along before Miranda?

context.speaker: Mark Alan Hart
context.text: Certainly.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I believe Mr. Justice Jackson said any lawyer worth this all who's going to tell the client not to talk until he, the lawyer, knows in private what he's going to say.

context.speaker: Mark Alan Hart
context.text: Well, we submit Your Honor that there might be indications where a lawyer would not make that statement to his client.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Perhaps after he'd had the private conversation.

Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.speaker: Justice Stevens
Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.case_name: Federal Communications Commission v. Midwest Video Corporation
Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 10, 1979

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Suppose next year or two, they do get enough period that they would like to put on, they are restricted as to just one thing --

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: That's right unless they want to build in additional capacity.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: They could build in 60 or 80 channels if they wanted to and provide converters to their subscribers and the rule would not require any more of it to be devoted to access than if they have a 20 channel system.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Following upon Mr. Justice Rehnquist's question about other licensee's isn't there a similarity between these rules and the prime time rules that say only three out of the four hours of prime time can be used for network television?

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: Well there is a similarity in the constitutional argument being made here.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: There are familiar rules, the prime time rule is a good example in which licensees and those authorized to use the broadcast signal are required to adjust the categories of programming that they can carry and in some cases to provide access broadcasters for example there is the personal attack rule, they have to provide access for response to personal attacks.

Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.speaker: Justice Stevens
Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.case_name: Federal Communications Commission v. Midwest Video Corporation
Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 10, 1979

context.speaker: George H. Shapiro
context.text: Initially a system will have 12 channels.

context.speaker: George H. Shapiro
context.text: The next incremental block tends to run another eight channels or so up to 20 and so forth.

context.speaker: George H. Shapiro
context.text: The access rules also require cable systems to adopt their own rules requiring that the use of their channels be provided on a first come non-discriminatory basis and prohibiting the cable system from exercising any program content control over the channels.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Shapiro, perhaps I shouldn't ask these kind of questions like Mr. Justice Rehnquist, does this converter that would increase capacity from 12 to 20 does that only goes on the sets or that goes on the cable system?

context.speaker: George H. Shapiro
context.text: Normally it goes on the set Your Honor.

context.speaker: George H. Shapiro
context.text: It's a little box that fits on top of the set and there is evidence in the record it costs about --

Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.speaker: Justice Burger
Federal Communications Commission v. Mid.case_name: Federal Communications Commission v. Midwest Video Corporation

context.text: Mr. Justice White will announce the judgment and opinion of the Court in Federal Communications Commission against Midwest Video Corporation and the consolidated cases.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This case is here from the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The case involves the validity of certain regulations issued by the Federal Communications Commission in 1976.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And as we understand the regulations at issue, they treat cable casters at least in part as common carriers.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This we have concluded and as we have explained in the opinion is forbidden by the Act.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We thus affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals as a matter of statutory construction without reaching the constitutional challenges presented to the regulations.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 648, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission against Pennzoil will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The principal issue in this case is whether into what extent the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has authority to grant special rate relief to natural gas producers who's royalty cost have escalated they are tied to the price of natural gas in unregulated market, the intrastate market.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Commission in its initial opinion seemed to indicate that it was without authority to grant such relief.

Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v..speaker: Justice White
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v..case_name: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v. Pennzoil Producing Company
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 16, 1979

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We do think the -- however that the entire case should be returned to the Commission so that the Commission may dispose of the case under the right standards.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And this remand of the Commission carries with it also a related issue about abandonment on which we think the Court of Appeals also erred.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordingly vacated and that Court is directed to return the case to the Commission.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.text: You don’t have a law suite, other way you would normally observe that District Court can simply say a snap judgment, I have known about this law so it burdensome, I would not require not burdensome, I will require -- he has got almost hypothetical law suit with the same sort effects, that you say we would have to go back for a trial.

context.speaker: Victor H. Kramer
context.text: Not quite Your Honor, I was refering to the broad issues of the types cited in each sides brief in this case, in which their experts said what impede effective market regulation, our expert said, it would make for a better market to publish promptly, so on.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Then your situation different the one hypothesized by Mr. Mr. Justice Rehnquist that in a law suit, there is a reason for trying to get information, presumably there is a reason.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You don’t spin your wheels trying to get your relevant information.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.text: But our point is that in discussing whether or not have they power, the Court should consider how this power should be exercised, is going to be exercised and if it is going to be exercised in a way that interferes with the state jurisdiction over production activates, then we think it conflicts with the jurisdiction of the state and exceeds the Commission jurisdictions.

context.text: Well, you have answered my question.

context.speaker: Dorothy Prengler
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Dorothy Prengler
context.text: Next in considering the consumers' interest in receiving valuable information, Section 513(d) does not restrict the information that is received by the consumer.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I ask you Justice Powell prompted a question for me.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Does your argument that this is not a violation of the First Amendment, would it applied to another statute prohibiting the use of trade names and other service industries, forget the product, but say in the cleaning business, you couldn't use the name ‘quality cleaner' or just something like that, would the State of Texas have the constitutional power to say, ‘we think cleaners ought to identify the owner and location', so would be the same issue?

context.speaker: Dorothy Prengler
context.text: Only if the state could find the type of abuses that are present in this particular case.

context.speaker: Dorothy Prengler
context.text: No, we would contend that the state would have a right to restrict the use of a trade name assuming that there has to be some reason.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Are you making a distinction between a chain of cleaning establishments, the quality cleaners on the one hand and other establishments that are dealing in services relating to health.

context.speaker: Dorothy Prengler
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I think that's the distinction that you make from Mr. Justice Powell's statements.

context.speaker: Dorothy Prengler
context.text: Yes sir, that would be certainly be a distinction in the use of a trade name to just sell products but certainly not have the same potential harms and consequences as it would in the health related field.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: What worries me is how much more information does an individual in a large city like Big D like Dallas get from the name NJ Rogers or the Rogers Optometric Corporation?

Friedman et al. v. Rogers et al.speaker: Justice Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion in No. 1163, 64, and 86, Friedman against Rogers will be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on appeal and cross-appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The District Court invalidated a section of the Texas Optometry Act that prohibited the practice of optometry under a trade name.

Friedman et al. v. Rogers et al.speaker: Justice Powell
Friedman et al. v. Rogers et al.case_name: Friedman et al. v. Rogers et al
Friedman et al. v. Rogers et al.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 21, 1979

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Since we conclude that the Texas law is a legitimate exercise of state authority, we reverse the decision of the District Court.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The Texas legislature also acted lawfully in requiring that a majority of the state's regulatory board be drawn from members of a professional organization, an organization that had standards consistent with the rules committed by the legislature to the board to enforce.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We therefore affirm the Court's decision sustaining that provision.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joined has filed a separate opinion concurring in the judgment with respect to the membership requirement but dissenting from the decision with respect to the trade name.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: Secondly, its -- if the order in this case is in a sense more dramatic than in Nebraska Press because not only is there a delay but there is an absolute denial of the public's knowledge of what went on in the suppression hearing.

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: As an appellate court, this Court is well aware of the inadequacies of a transcript but the tones, inflections, gestures, everything that makes a presence of a -- of the trier of facts so necessary into a determination, none of those things can be recaptured in the transcript.

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: And finally --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But if you -- but if (Inaudible) as Mr. Justice Stevens suggested, if the interest of justice and fairness require that the jury not here change of the evidence, how is that purpose served?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I'm not sure you quite fully answered and how is that purpose served if the jury hears it indirectly?

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: Your Honor, we make no argument at all that suppression hearings must be open under all circumstances.

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: I would've argued that there was no basis for the closure Your Honor that --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, on the ground that whatever was the subject to the motion to suppress had already been published?

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: That's one aspect to it that that closure would be ineffective because we could -- it's not a gag order on the press, they could publish the singly most prejudicial statement that could be made is that the defendants confessed and we could have published that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You said earlier Mr. Bernius in response to Justice Stevens that the defendants' right was not paramount.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I think those were your words.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You mean it's -- the defendants' right to a fair trial is not paramount?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: On what ground then?

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: Under the Nebraska Press test Your Honor.

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: But the fact that --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But the -- Judge DePasquale apparently anticipated your answer to Mr. Justice Brennan, didn't he?

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: The colloquy among lawyers who are involved in this Your Honor is that this is -- this situation is a direct result of the Nebraska press decision and it's our feeling that the mechanism even though the mechanism is ejection rather than injunction, the damages are at least as great and the standards in Nebraska Press should be complied with.

context.speaker: Robert C. Bernius
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would that (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Bernard Kobroff
context.text: -- cannot be prior -- cannot be a subject to a prior restraint.

context.speaker: Bernard Kobroff
context.text: So that option was never even available to him as far as that goes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would that fall within what I think Mr. Justice Frankfurter said once the cat is out of the bag, it's impossible to get it back in again.

context.speaker: Bernard Kobroff
context.text: That seems to be the rule.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What was the judge's decision in this case on admissibility?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 77-1051, Givhan against Western Line Consolidated School District will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In this case, petitioner Givhan was a junior high school English teacher in a rural consolidated school district in Northern Mississippi.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: When the school district fired her, she filed an action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi seeking reinstatement on the grounds that nonrenewal of her First Amendment right to freedom of speech.

Givhan v. Western Line Consolidated Scho.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Givhan v. Western Line Consolidated Scho.case_name: Givhan v. Western Line Consolidated School District
Givhan v. Western Line Consolidated Scho.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 09, 1979

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Nor is the Court of Appeals' view supported by the captive audience rationale for having agreed to listen to the teacher's views, the principal was hardly in the position to argue that he was an unwilling recipient of.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The First Amendment forbids governmental abridgment of the freedom of speech whether that speech is expressed publicly to the world at large or privately to other individuals.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We remand the case to the District Court however for consideration of the school district's claim that petitioner's contract would not have been renewed even if her private encounters with the principal had not taken place.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens while joining the opinion of the Court has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But you would say, the claimant would have been injured by the housing practice, that is a broader concept than the direct victim concept.

context.speaker: Jonathan T. Howe
context.text: When you talk of injury, you talk about something that somebody has incurred as a result of a housing discrimination.

context.speaker: Jonathan T. Howe
context.text: Maybe that housing discrimination was not directed at them, but they do sustain some injury whereas with the right, we contend Your Honor that, that is individual.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I understand your argument, but maybe I am just repeating what Mr. Justice Marshall asked, but is there anything in the legislative history, the language of the statute that you can point to that says there is this distinction between direct and indirect victims?

context.speaker: Jonathan T. Howe
context.text: No, Your Honor and we submit the reason that we cannot do that is because Congress never considered the distinction between a direct or indirect victim but rather throughout, the thread of the legislative history was that they were talking about people who were barred access to housing.

context.speaker: Jonathan T. Howe
context.text: They were talking of direct victims.

context.text: I will say only that in an earlier case, Trafficante against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, we sustained standing under Section 810 of the Act of plaintiffs who wish to preserve the integrated character of a large apartment complex.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We conclude today that much of the reasoning in our decision with respect to Section 810 applies also to this action brought under Section 812.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We think that the Village of Bellwood, a municipality and its residents who instituted this suit, have averred actual injury as a result of the racial steering allegedly practice by the real estate firms.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Stewart has joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Keith E. Kaiser
context.text: I just don't want the Court to think that I'm coming in here arguing for the automobile casualty insurance industry when I'm not.

context.speaker: Keith E. Kaiser
context.text: We believe that the health insurance industry is some what different.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, I happened to do disagree with my brother Stewart's comment that your answer that Justice Stevens' question helps you rather than hurts you and I don't see the bright line that you're talking about between an agreement on the part of and casualty insurance company with a law firm to defend its policyholders in lawsuits in which they're sued and an agreement with drugstores or pharmaceutical houses to provide drugs where the causality insured against is the need of drugs.

context.speaker: Keith E. Kaiser
context.text: Your Honor, we think that the proper line is that an agreement -- a third party agreement which relates directly to the provision of benefits.

context.speaker: Keith E. Kaiser
context.text: Those benefits which are under written in the policy and anything in that agreement which directly relates to the cost of those benefits to be delivered and which are under written in the policy would constitute a part of the business of insurance from McCarran-Ferguson purposes.

context.speaker: Jonathan W. Lubell
context.text: I think --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But if it were told him by some outsider, you could inquire into that?

context.speaker: Jonathan W. Lubell
context.text: It may well -- I can't say, I would argue obviously if it came up in the District Court, I would argue if you could, but I don't -- I cannot say with confidence that, that answer is supported by the two decisions which form the majority.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well assuming now Mr. Lubell the question suggested by Justice White has been answered, in that he has had two statements made to that are not consistent.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Under this opinion or of these collective opinions, do you think you cannot ask why did you publish this and why did you omit that?

context.speaker: Jonathan W. Lubell
context.text: No, I do not think and it would be quite clear on this, I do not think we could ask that.

context.speaker: Floyd Abrams
context.text: Who did you talk to?

context.speaker: Floyd Abrams
context.text: Who did you interview as judge Kaufman said the form and frequency of communications with sources, including transcripts of interviews.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What about a question?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What did you believe as the Mr. Justice Brennan said when you were told that, what was your reaction?

context.speaker: Floyd Abrams
context.text: Well, that I think Mr. Justice Rehnquist gets a lot closer to what answers were not given in this case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, but that's a real problem for plaintiffs in cases like this that's having in my own practice been a party on both sides to fraud cases and defamation cases, you don't get admissions out of defendants mouths that they lied, you have to go after them in tangential ways?

context.speaker: Floyd Abrams
context.text: We think that Justice Marshall that question --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: You wouldn't object to it because you would know what the answer would be?

context.speaker: Floyd Abrams
context.text: I know what the answers would be to all of these questions.[Attempt to Laughter]

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But that's the ultimate issue in the case of the New York Times against Sullivan what justice Marshall was asking, isn't it?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: One of the ultimate facts that a jury has to determine is whether he did that with reckless disregard to the two?

context.speaker: Floyd Abrams
context.text: That's right -- and what I said is that, we have not -- Mr. Lubell has not asked these question, but we would not have objected it and we do not maintain that the privilege that we seek here protects against a response to the question about whether anything that was on the program was believed by the journalist or was known by the journalist to be untrue.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 1105, Herbert against Lando will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This case involves a defamation action which began when petitioner, Anthony Herbert, sued Columbia Broadcasting System and two principal participants in the CBS network broadcast containing various statements about Herbert that allegedly were false and damaging to his reputation.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Because Herbert was a public figure as that term is understood in the law of libel and slander, his burden was to prove not only false and damaging publication but one that the defendants' knew or should have known was false.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Because of the First and Fourteenth Amendments, the plaintiff's burden in this case was to prove a knowing or reckless falsehood and we do not agree that the amendment should also prevent the plaintiff from seeking direct evidence from the defendants about a critical part of his case.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We leave the First Amendment as it is and decline to construe it to create the absolute privilege for the categories of evidence involved in this case.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordingly reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell while joining the Court's opinion has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed an opinion dissenting in part.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: He agrees with the majority that Lando was not privileged to refuse to answer questions about his own beliefs as to the truth of the material he gathered.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We leave the First Amendment as it is and decline to construe it to create the absolute privilege for the categories of evidence involved in this case.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordingly reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell while joining the Court's opinion has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed an opinion dissenting in part.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: He agrees with the majority that Lando was not privileged to refuse to answer questions about his own beliefs as to the truth of the material he gathered.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But Mr. Justice Brennan would protect against inquiry into editorial conversation until there has been a prima facie showing of falsehood as a publication.

context.speaker: James D. Endman
context.text: I think if the trial court is prevented from taking into consideration the issue of railroad retirement fund.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well this is the next step, it is taken into consideration and maybe making your client just go with something else wholly apart from the inability to touch the benefit fund.

context.speaker: James D. Endman
context.text: Well, I think this would be inconsistent with the prohibition against illegal process, any legal attempt on the part of the California courts to deal with the railroad retirement fund.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, all I'm suggesting that might that I think this is what Mr. Justice Rehnquist had in mind and I don't believe you've answered it is that all it's doing in adding up assets is destroying the benefit from into the computation without touching it but drawing on some other assets in determining the appropriate share of the community.

context.speaker: James D. Endman
context.text: Well that that --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: You say they can't do this.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Let me take a simple way of looking at it.

context.speaker: Howard M. Fields
context.text: Well, the divorce is a legal proceeding but the aspect of adding up this benefit as a community property asset is really not a legal process per se.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Fields can I just follow up on one thought.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall asked you of what in your view the word “anticipated” meant and I didn't understand your answer.

context.speaker: Howard M. Fields
context.text: My answer was that again, this was a word included in an exemption statute enacted during the depression.

context.speaker: Howard M. Fields
context.text: It was -- we believed taken out of contexts, out of the language of the spendthrift trust and if we follow through in petitioner's argument that the court cannot evaluate the community interest in this benefit because the respondent would be anticipating that benefit.

context.speaker: Herma Hill Kay
context.text: It would be treated if you please as an asset generated by the husband's work during marriage.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well if it is community property --

context.speaker: Herma Hill Kay
context.text: That is correct, if it is --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But Mr. Justice Stevens said if the Government is correct in this case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Then it's a husband's assets and it is not going to --

context.speaker: Herma Hill Kay
context.text: Well, oh, I beg your pardon here, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 77-533, Hisquierdo against Hisquierdo will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well this case comes to us by writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of the State of California.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The petitioner and the respondent are California residents.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today with the clerk we reverse.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We hold that benefits payable under the Act may not be divided under the state's community property law to require the employee to pay respondent a portion of the anticipated benefits or its monetary equivalent would contravene the statute and deprive the employee of a portion of a benefit that Congress indicated was designed for the employee alone.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Under the Supremacy Clause of the constitution, the state must defer to the Act's statutory scheme for allocating benefits insofar as the terms of federal law require.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to state that Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion and joined in that opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun

context.text: I'm authorized to state that Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion and joined in that opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We hold that benefits payable under the Act may not be divided under the state's community property law to require the employee to pay respondent a portion of the anticipated benefits or its monetary equivalent would contravene the statute and deprive the employee of a portion of a benefit that Congress indicated was designed for the employee alone.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Under the Supremacy Clause of the constitution, the state must defer to the Act's statutory scheme for allocating benefits insofar as the terms of federal law require.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to state that Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion and joined in that opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa.speaker: Justice Burger
Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa.case_name: Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa
Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - NOVEMBER 28, 1978

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Holt Civic Club and others against the City of Tuscaloosa will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Holt, Alabama is a rural unincorporated community located just outside the corporate limits of Tuscaloosa, Alabama but within Tuscaloosa's three-mile police jurisdiction.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Residents of Holt and an incorporated civic association brought this suit alleging that Alabama statutes subjecting police jurisdiction residents to Tuscaloosa's police and sanitary regulations to the criminal jurisdiction of Tuscaloosa's court and to the city's power to license businesses without also extending to police jurisdiction residents the right to vote in municipal elections violated their rights under the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment of the constitution.

Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa.case_name: Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa
Holt Civic Club v. City of Tuscaloosa.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - NOVEMBER 28, 1978

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They are however like any other litigant entitled to claim that Alabama statute permitting Tuscaloosa to enforce some of its ordinances within the police jurisdiction denies them the equal protection of the laws secured by the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States constitution.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We conclude however that Alabama's police jurisdiction statutes are rationally related to the state's interest in affording municipalities some measure of control over activities conducted just beyond their corporate limits and ensuring that police jurisdiction residents do not go without basic municipal services such as police, fire, and health protection.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Alabama statute here challenge does not therefore deny appellants the equal protection of the laws because it does not do so appellants likewise state no separate claim under Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because they are denied the franchise.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens while joining the opinion of the Court has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan joined by Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Number 1439, Hughes against Oklahoma will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It concerns the constitutionality under the Commerce Clause of an Oklahoma statute that makes it a crime to transport or ship out of Oklahoma for sale natural minnows seined or procured from waters within the State.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we, today, expressly overrule Geer v. Connecticut and hold that state regulations of wild animals must be tested by the general rule applied to state regulations of other natural resources, namely, whether the challenged statute regulates evenhandedly with only incidental effects on interstate commerce, or discriminates against interstate commerce either on its face or in practical effect, and if the statute serves some legitimate local purpose whether alternative means could promote that purpose without discriminating against interstate commerce.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And tested by that standard, we hold for reasons detailed in the opinion filed today that the Oklahoma statute is repugnant to the Commerce Clause.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist joined by the Chief Justice dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And tested by that standard, we hold for reasons detailed in the opinion filed today that the Oklahoma statute is repugnant to the Commerce Clause.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist joined by the Chief Justice dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: James C. Bonner, Jr.
context.text: In a normal case, when a judge is passing sentence, and incidentally, I want to stress too that we're not making any suggestion at all that the judge should not consider or should not be aware of economic status.

context.speaker: James C. Bonner, Jr.
context.text: It's our position that the more he knows about that infinite, the wiser and the better his judgment can be.

context.speaker: James C. Bonner, Jr.
context.text: But he's got to treat that factor like raise as Justice Jackson said in Edwards versus California as a neutral fact, one that is neither the source of rights nor a basis for denying them.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Bonner, I don't understand on how you can give us the answer you did to both Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We'll hear arguments first this morning in Hutchinson against Proxmire and others.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Peter J. Barack
context.text: We do know that by the defendant's own computations when there has been an investment along the example they use of approximately $9500.00 in the pension fund that there would be substantial profits returned to the investor and now these substantial profits approximately $5000.00 would represent earnings on that fund were approximately 50% of the amount invested.

context.speaker: Peter J. Barack
context.text: Let's look at it from another point of view, the people -- the persons investing in this fund investing $30.00 a week, $1500.00 a year or over $30,000.00 on a 20-year career, if invested risk-free at 7.5% in the savings bank that would amount to $72,000.00 over 22 -- a 20-year career.

context.speaker: Peter J. Barack
context.text: So the profit potential is tremendous and this is what induces these people to invest here.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: When Mr. McDaniel signed the pass -- signed on in the pension agreement as recently formulated to prog -- guarantee him on $240.00 or $250.00 a month as Justice Stevens questions you about, was there any promise that he would get more than that if the investments went well?

context.speaker: Peter J. Barack
context.text: We believe that the facts when we get to trial in this case will indicate --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, what -- was there any provision in the agreement to that effect?

context.speaker: Terrence R. Fitzgerald

context.speaker: Terrence R. Fitzgerald
context.text: And the reason that these factors were going into and impress me was to see whether or not it had to be done in this particular manner with this particular instruction.

context.speaker: Terrence R. Fitzgerald

Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regi.speaker: Justice Burger
Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regi.case_name: Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency
Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regi.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 05, 1979

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Number 1327, Lake Country Estates, Incorporated, against Tahoe Regional Planning Agency will be announced by Mr. Justice Stevens and he will also announce State of Nevada against Hall.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Both of these cases they have special interest to people from Nevada and California although the two cases are unrelated.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The principle question in the first of the case is Number 77-1327 is whether the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency which was created by a compact between the States of California and Nevada is entitled to claim the same immunity from suit in a federal court that the States themselves have under the Eleventh Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regi.speaker: Justice Stevens
Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regi.case_name: Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency
Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regi.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 05, 1979

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held that the Agency is immune from suit and further held that when the members of the Agency’s governing body are performing legislative acts, they are entitled to the same immunity as state legislators.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Today, we unanimously hold that the Regional Planning Agency does not have the same immunity under the Eleventh Amendment as the States do.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And by vote of six to three, we hold that the individual defendants have a personal immunity comparable to that of state legislators.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: On the latter issue, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun have filed dissenting opinions.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We therefore affirm in part and reverse in part the decision of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held that the Agency is immune from suit and further held that when the members of the Agency’s governing body are performing legislative acts, they are entitled to the same immunity as state legislators.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Today, we unanimously hold that the Regional Planning Agency does not have the same immunity under the Eleventh Amendment as the States do.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And by vote of six to three, we hold that the individual defendants have a personal immunity comparable to that of state legislators.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: On the latter issue, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun have filed dissenting opinions.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We therefore affirm in part and reverse in part the decision of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Leonard M. Henkin
context.text: She just did not appeal.

context.speaker: Leonard M. Henkin
context.text: She did not file any brief and she did not appear although, after we filed a notice of appealed for the second time.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Would you tell me one other thing.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I'm not sure I understood you answer to Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: He asked you if there -- whether there's a lot of money involved or small amount.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You answered by saying there's a $100,000.00 bond posted I don't really know how that answers the question.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on appeal for the New York Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Under a New York statute, illegitimate children may inherit from their intestate fathers only if they have obtained a judicial order of paternity during the father's lifetime.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: A judicial decree assures reliable evidence of paternity reducing the possibility of fraud, error, and delay.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Nor is this an unduly burdensome method of establishing paternity.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We therefore hold that New York's solution to this problem satisfies the requirement of the Equal Protection Clause.

context.speaker: Clyde O. Martz
context.text: The issue today is not really whether the United States or any other private party has a right of access to cross a section of land to reach an adjoining section of land.

context.speaker: Clyde O. Martz
context.text: The kind of case in which this question is being raised is precisely the kind that gave rise to this controversy, the construction of a roadway across a ranch area for access not of a few people but of the public to a recreational area without fencing the road for the protection of the integrity of the ranching area.

context.speaker: Clyde O. Martz
context.text: These are the kind of questions in which this issue will be raised and it's on these kinds of questions that we need clarification of these rights.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Generations of land patents have issued without any express reference to rights now claimed by the Government and this Court as well as other courts had traditionally recognized that special need for certainty and predictability where land titles are concerned.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We are unwilling to accept the Government's invitation to upset settled expectations to accommodate some ill-defined power to construct public thoroughfares through private property without compensation.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals was accordingly reversed.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Peter E. Heiser, Jr.
context.text: That is a matter of the -- it's a matter of whether one wants to call it venue or proper assertion of personal jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Peter E. Heiser, Jr.

context.speaker: Peter E. Heiser, Jr.
context.text: That's the purpose of trying to stop the form shopping.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, what if Congress says in so many words that if there has been a violation of the Act, as Mr. Justice White's question to assume, process may be served and personal jurisdiction may be obtained in any one of the 93 judicial districts in the United States?

context.speaker: Peter E. Heiser, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist, if that is what the statute said, then I would still try to be here before you saying that that statute in assessing personal jurisdiction on such a broad scope was missing the very important due process requirement that allows the federal court to hear the case in the first place.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well would you say that even in a case where the prosecution or the action arose in a case where the alleged violation occurred?

context.speaker: Peter E. Heiser, Jr.
context.text: Absolutely Your Honor.

context.speaker: Peter E. Heiser, Jr.
context.text: But it's our contention that both of them are absolutely wrongly decided because both of them misapplied not only the due process standards, but fail to come to grips with the doing business prerequisite on the one hand and the Texas long-arm statute.

context.speaker: Peter E. Heiser, Jr.
context.text: And created this incredible fiction that state officials who were enforcing a state law in Idaho themselves regulators of securities transaction were somehow guilty of the same type of activity that people who were subject to the Williams Act and the other portions of the Securities Exchange Act violate.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But that -- that's answering the question that Mr. Justice White earlier asked you to assume.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But supposing that they go into the Northern District of Texas and alleged that you have -- that you have made -- violated the Securities Act and alleged venue and jurisdiction under Section 27.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, don't you think that Congress has a right to allow that sort of jurisdiction and venue if it's expressly says so, and if it can satisfactorily -- if the plans can satisfactorily make out a case that you have violated the thing?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.text: The First National Bank of Omaha, Nebraska is a national bank chartered in Nebraska.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Minnesota Supreme Court reached that conclusion on the ground that as a national bank, the Omaha Bank is a federal instrumentality whose interest rate for its BankAmericard program is governed by federal law, and federal law, the National Bank Act, 12 United States Code Section 85, authorizes a national bank to charge interests on any loan at the rate allowed by the laws of the State where the bank is and the word of the statute is located.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Minnesota Supreme Court held that the Omaha Bank for the purposes of the statute was located in Nebraska, therefore, authorize the charge in Nebraska 18% rate.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We agree and unanimously affirm the judgment of the Minnesota Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Robert S. Cohen
context.text: Alternatively respondent argues that some policy reasons argue against the use of a good faith defense in situations like the case at bar.

context.speaker: Robert S. Cohen
context.text: A good faith defense puts the premium on ignorance of the law and would be an additional – it would add an additional and exceptionally difficult fact finding process to the already overburdened criminal law process.

context.speaker: Robert S. Cohen
context.text: Further the existence of such a defense could generate uncertainty and invite calculated risks on the part of the police, thereby defeating the primary goal of Miranda to give to the police concrete constitutional guidelines.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Counsel, what’s your reply to Mr. Justice White’s concurring opinion in Stone v. Powell that exclusion of evidence obtained in good faith will never have a deterrent effect because if people are acting in good faith and reasonably they will presumably do the same thing again.

context.speaker: Robert S. Cohen
context.text: Well, I would say that number one, the police officer in this case did not act in good faith.

context.speaker: Robert S. Cohen
context.text: The evidence indicates that the police officer knew that the respondent had not waived his rights to counsel and his right against the self incrimination.

context.text: Certainly and that demonstrates that there was, there is split among the circuits because the Fifth Circuit is held to the contrary.

context.text: In which case did you mention Justice Powell's concurring opinion?

context.text: That was in Brown versus Illinois.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: He was the author of Stone against Powell.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now that's the hypothesis we have to work from here, isn't it, even though perhaps the Court of Appeals might have found it differently, had the case been argued different.

context.speaker: James C. Howarth
context.text: I would agree with that.

context.speaker: James C. Howarth
context.text: The only point that we make on that is that it is not 100% certain that Mr. DeFillippo did in fact continue to represent to the officer that he was in fact a fellow Detroit police officer.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Are telling us we should not accept what Mr. Justice Rehnquist just read to you out of the opinion.

context.speaker: James C. Howarth
context.text: No I am not, what I am --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Either accept it or we don't, and if we accept it we can't accept any of your hypotheses.

context.speaker: Robert A. Derengoski
context.text: Perhaps sir, perhaps.

context.speaker: Robert A. Derengoski
context.text: The --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Or are you suggesting the Michigan jails are warmer in Arizona?

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I share with Mr. Justice Stewart's confusion that (Voice Overlap).

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Or are you suggesting that it doesn't take much imagination to know why.

context.speaker: Robert A. Derengoski
context.text: Obviously, he did not want the Arizona conviction and probable sentence that would follow.

context.speaker: Kathleen M.Cummins
context.text: Because there's no indication of the facts upon which a neutral and detached finding a probable cause could have been made.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, that's saying that she acted wrongly not that she was not neutral and detached.

context.speaker: Kathleen M.Cummins
context.text: Part of the neutral and detached requirement extends to whether or not the facts are sufficient to convince -- a) to support an independent finding, a detached finding, and b) to satisfy the review in Court, that such a detached finding was made.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In Shadwick against City of Tampa which Justice Powell wrote for the Court some years ago, we held that city clerks of this Tampa were neutral and detached magistrates.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And I don't think we felt that incumbent to review all the probable cause determination they've made over the course of six months or year to decide whether they're neutral and detached.

context.text: It's just wasn't separate from prosecuting her.

context.text: The opinions for the Court in No. 77-742, Miller v. Youakim, 77-1134, Montana v. United States, and 77-1248, Illinois State Board of Elections versus Socialist Workers Party will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the 77-742, this is from the Seventh Circuit and the case presents the question whether Illinois may prohibit foster children to live with relatives from participating in its Aid to Families with Dependent Children-Foster Care program of Illinois.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Under the Illinois statute, foster children placed by the state with unrelated caretakers are eligible for the foster care program.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Department of Health, Education, and Welfare also interpret the statute to include foster children placed with relatives.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This interpretation by the agency charged with administering the program is entitled to considerable deference.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And that litigation concluded in a decision by the Montana Supreme Court upholding the tax.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The federal court then heard the instant case on the merits, and concluded that the United States was not bound by the earlier state court judgment that the tax violated the Supremacy Clause.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Because we hold that the United States was collaterally estopped from charging issues previously resolved against it in the state court, we reverse the federal court's decision without reaching the merits of the constitutional question.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.text: It appears so that the burden, the state was putting the burden on the family to go in and to accord themselves a hearing.

context.speaker: Windell Porter
context.text: As all of the time the children were in the custody of the state and I might point out that even though the case was transferred to Montgomery County where no action was taken in Montgomery County and it was transferred with a show cause hearing that the children remained in the custody for the entire 42-day period of the Harris County Child Welfare.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Ms Porter like did Justice Marshall, I don't understand why nobody on behalf of the parents, when the children are out of their custody all this of period ran into the --- why didn't they go to the Montgomery County Court and say, hey, I want our children back.

context.text: Apparently sir, and this is just information, this is not in the record.

context.text: And I read it frankly to prohibit solicitation in the corridor because I thought the Board didn't treat corridor as patient care areas.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think that's what Mr. Justice Powell was asking you too.

context.speaker: Norton J. Come
context.text: Well, I think -- I think that what the Board order says is that the hospital just cannot have a blanket ban in these public areas.

context.speaker: Norton J. Come
context.text: What they have to do is to define with more precision what are their patient care areas and even with respect to nonpatient care areas.
