context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, ordinarily the Full Faith and Credit relates to acts and events, which have occurred within the state which is asking Full Faith and Credit be given to its law, not -- this is an extra territorial effect that you are asking for, it would appear of the Nevada Law.

context.speaker: Michael Dyer
context.text: We are not asking for an extra territorial effect in Nevada law.

context.speaker: Michael Dyer
context.text: Our position in a nutshell is that any state must acknowledge the status of our sister states as a sovereign.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What particular provision of the constitution, I think Mr. Justice Stewart was probing for that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What particular provision of the constitution tells us that?

context.speaker: Michael Dyer
context.text: The constitution, and I'm trying to ask the question Mr. Chief Justice and I'm not trying to side step, but I want to address this question, because I think it is perhaps the most important --

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Nevada claims that it is either entirely immune from suit in the courts of the sister state or at the very least that the recovery should be limited to $25,000, which is the maximum amount that could be recovered if Nevada had been sued in its own courts.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In an opinion filed with the clerk today, we point out that the doctrine of sovereign immunity actually encompasses two quite different concepts. One applicable to suits in the sovereign’s own courts and the other to suits in the court’s of another sovereign.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: With respect to the former, only the sovereign’s consent can qualify the absolute character of its immunity.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But with respect to the latter, as Chief Justice Marshall explained in a case decided in 1812 involving an attempt to assert jurisdiction over the Emperor of France, immunity is a matter of comity determined by the laws of the sovereign in whose courts the claim is asserted.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Although it has been the prevailing practice throughout our history for sovereigns to accord one another immunity as a matter of comity, California has now decided to adopt the different policy in its courts.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We find nothing in the Federal Constitution that prevents California from making this determination as a matter of state law, nor do we find any constitutional basis for Nevada’s claim that it is either immune from suit in the California courts or that California must respect the limitation on liability that would apply if Nevada had been sued in its own courts.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Although it has been the prevailing practice throughout our history for sovereigns to accord one another immunity as a matter of comity, California has now decided to adopt the different policy in its courts.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We find nothing in the Federal Constitution that prevents California from making this determination as a matter of state law, nor do we find any constitutional basis for Nevada’s claim that it is either immune from suit in the California courts or that California must respect the limitation on liability that would apply if Nevada had been sued in its own courts.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Accordingly, we reject Nevada’s claim and we affirm the judgment of the California Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have filed scholarly dissenting opinions in which the Chief Justice has joined.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by reason of the grant of certiorari to the review of the judgment of the Superior Court of New Jersey Appellate Division.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The case involves the scope of the privilege against compulsory self-incrimination grounded in the Fifth Amendment and made binding against the States by the Fourteenth.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The courts are not free therefore in a case like this to engage in a process of balancing the competitive interests involved.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Any such balancing was performed finally and forever or at least until the constitution is amended by our forefathers.

context.text: For these reasons more fully elaborated in the written opinion filed this morning with the clerk, the judgment of the New Jersey Court is affirmed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in New Motor Vehicle Board of California against Fox and the consolidated case will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This is an appeal from a judgment of a three-judge District Court in the Central District of California declaring unconstitutional the California Automobile Franchise Act.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Under that Act, a motor vehicle manufacturer must secure the approval of the California New Motor Vehicle Board before opening a retail motor vehicle dealership within the market area of an existing franchisee but if and only if that existing franchisee protests the establishment of the competing dealership.

New Motor Vehicle Board of California v..speaker: Justice Brennan
New Motor Vehicle Board of California v..case_name: New Motor Vehicle Board of California v. Orrin W. Fox Company
New Motor Vehicle Board of California v..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 05, 1978

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And we hold there is no conflict with the Sherman Act.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The statutory scheme is a system of regulation designed to displace unfettered business freedom in establishing and relocating automobile dealerships and hence it's outside the reach of the antitrust laws under the state action exemption of Parker and Brown.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Moreover, to the extent that there is a conflict with the Sherman Act because the Act does permit dealers to invoke state powers for the purpose of restraining intraband competition, that conflict cannot itself constitute a sufficient reason for invalidating the statute for if an adverse effect on competition were in and of itself enough to render a state statute invalid, the state's power to engage in economic regulation would be effectively destroyed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall joining the Court opinion has also filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun was joined by Mr. Justice Powell has filed an opinion concurring in the result.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.text: Moreover, to the extent that there is a conflict with the Sherman Act because the Act does permit dealers to invoke state powers for the purpose of restraining intraband competition, that conflict cannot itself constitute a sufficient reason for invalidating the statute for if an adverse effect on competition were in and of itself enough to render a state statute invalid, the state's power to engage in economic regulation would be effectively destroyed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall joining the Court opinion has also filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun was joined by Mr. Justice Powell has filed an opinion concurring in the result.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Deborah M. Greenberg
context.text: It is a rule that no one may use certain kinds of drugs without permission, written permission of the Medical Director.

context.speaker: Deborah M. Greenberg
context.text: The Transit Authority does not exclude from employment or terminate from employment persons who use other drugs that are encompassed within that rule, for example amphetamines or tranquilizers.

context.speaker: Deborah M. Greenberg
context.text: In that case, it makes an investigation to see whether there is some reason why the person should be using those drugs.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Just like Mr. Justice Rehnquist asked about the statute, cannot we look at the rule as thought it were somewhat like a statute and we have to determine its meaning by the way it has been construed and it has been construed in some of these fringe areas to require individualized treatment, and in other areas, it includes methadone users.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me the basic classification you are challenging, is this classification made by the rule as interpreted by the Transit Authority.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You are saying it is too broad a rule?

New York City Transit Authority v. Beaze.speaker: Justice Stevens
New York City Transit Authority v. Beaze.case_name: New York City Transit Authority v. Beazer
New York City Transit Authority v. Beaze.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 21, 1979

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The departure by those courts from the procedure normally followed in addressing statutory and constitutional questions in the same case as well as concerned that the merits of these important questions have been decided erroneously led us to grant certiorari.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We now reverse.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Without reaching the question whether it would be unlawful for the Transit Authority to refuse to employ persons who have successfully completed a methadone treatment program, the Court holds that the policy of refusing to employ current users of methadone does not violate either Title VII of the Civil Rights Act or the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting statement and Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Marshall has joined.

context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stevens.

context.text: Then, why keep pushing for it?

context.speaker: Maria L. Marcus
context.text: It was I believe an answer to a question about what the Social Security Act did and I think it's clear that its structure was to give this broad permission, but what's I think equally significant here is that New Yorks law existed at the time that the Social Security Act, the National Labor Relations Act were passed.

context.speaker: Maria L. Marcus
context.text: And so it's clear that --

New York Telephone Company v. New York D.speaker: Justice Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens has the two judgment -- two opinions -- judgment and opinion of the court to announce, one, 961, New York Telephone Company against New York State Department of Labor and the other, 1427, New York City Transit Authority against Beazer.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In the New York Telephone Company case, the question is whether federal law prohibits the state of New York from paying unemployment compensation to strikers.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The case arises out of the prolonged strike against the New York Telephone Company by members of the Communication Workers of America. During a period of approximately five months, the state paid weekly benefits averaging roughly $75 a week per employee to about 33,000 striking employees.

New York Telephone Company v. New York D.speaker: Justice Stevens
New York Telephone Company v. New York D.case_name: New York Telephone Company v. New York Department of Labor
New York Telephone Company v. New York D.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 21, 1979

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That court held that Congress had not expressly forbidden state unemployment compensation for strikers and after reviewing the legislative history of the National Labor Relations Act and Title IX of the Social Security Act concluded that Congress did not implicitly prohibit the states from paying this kind of compensation to striking employees.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Because of the importance of the issue, this Court granted certiorari and now affirms the judgment of the Court of Appeals. The reasons for the Court's conclusions are set forth in three separate opinions.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I would only say about those reasons that they make it clear that the question is not a constitutional question but rather is a question of what Congress has intended in the various -- in the relevant statutes that it has enacted.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I have filed an opinion joined by Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a separate concurring opinion.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And Mr. Justice Blackmun joined by Mr. Justice Marshall has also filed an opinion concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Right and, Mr. Braswell, the opinion of the Supreme Court of North Carolina which decided this case in your favor seems to be inconsistent in its statement of the facts with the answer you just gave to my Brother Stevens.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It says in the last paragraph of the page, on page 83 of the appendix to the petition, says when he was arrested in New York at 1225 Chardon Avenue in Brooklyn, he was immediately and fully advised of his constitutional rights and transported to the New Rochelle office where he was again advised of his rights.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Defendant, who had an 11th Grade education, then took the advice of rights form and read it himself.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now, you said that, just in answer to Justice Stevens, that all that was done at the New Rochelle office was to give him the right -- the advice of rights form and let him read it himself.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That's not what this opinion says.

context.speaker: R. Gene Braswell
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In conflict with the view of every other court that has considered the issue, the North Carolina Supreme Court has held in this case that under this Court’s decision in Miranda against Arizona, no statement of a person under custodial interrogation may be admitted in evidence against him unless at the time the statement was made, he explicitly waived the right to the presence of a lawyer.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We granted certiorari to consider whether this per se rule reflects a proper understanding of the Miranda decision.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in an opinion of the Court filed today, the judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to North Carolina Supreme Court for further proceedings.

context.speaker: John L. Capell, III
context.text: Yes sir, if you are following that statement of that being quashed, if you look at Justice Almon's statement, which is a concurring opinion with the majority, you will see that it states and I am quoting in essence that any statute which favors women against men is constitutional.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I take it he concurred specially because the majority did not agree with it, that is what the experience we usually have here?

context.speaker: John L. Capell, III
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And the majority are simply silent and I am wondering in view of our long established rule that one must raise the constitutional issue at the very first point in any state proceeding and must renew it throughout that if Justice Powell's question to you does not suggest that perhaps the Supreme of Alabama thought the Alabama Appellate Court was wrong in passing on the constitutionality of the issue?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The if the result was right, but that it simply should not have opined on the constitutionality?

context.speaker: John L. Capell, III
context.text: I would like to respectfully state that opinion would not be the reason Your Honor, I would like to maintain before this Court that Mr. Orr does have a standing based on the facts of the Alabama statutes as we have specified.

context.speaker: John L. Capell, III
context.text: But it does, but it strictly related to man thing not women paying sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Wasn't the divorce Court relying on a settlement agreement here?

context.speaker: John L. Capell, III
context.text: Yes sir, it wherein the state is the third party.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: [Voice Overlap] as Mr. Justice Powell pointed out, the court didn't have to make any decision except to pass on the settlement agreement, did he?

context.speaker: John L. Capell, III
context.text: That's why and under the state statute Mr. Chief Justice, they being the third-party involved in each divorce suit, don't look to the fairness of the award as they should which is our contention.

context.speaker: John L. Capell, III
context.text: They look to see if the wife is protected; I am relying on the standard case which is applied to the attached --

context.speaker: W. F. Horsley
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And where does that case?

context.speaker: W. F. Horsley
context.text: Where is --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The only case you've got is Mr. Justice Stewart is talking about so far?

context.speaker: W. F. Horsley
context.text: The -- all of the --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: You have any – thought beside that in the Alabama courts?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well then you don't grant divorces by stipulation in Alabama, do you?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There must have been at least in implicit finding of faults or the Court wouldn't have the jurisdiction, would it?

context.speaker: W. F. Horsley
context.text: Well, we do have no file divorce in Alabama, incompatibility is also ground for the divorce.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I turn back to Mr. Justice White's question.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This divorce is under 51, not 52 or 53?

context.speaker: W. F. Horsley
context.text: I think 52 Your Honor, wasn't --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 1119, Orr against Orr will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on certiorari to the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It presents the question whether the Alabama alimony statutes' effect in unconstitutional gender-based discrimination.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But even statutes purportedly designed to compensate for and ameliorate the effects of past discrimination must be carefully tailored to satisfy the Equal Protection Clause.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Our opinion demonstrates that the state's compensatory and ameliorative purposes are as well served by a gender-neutral classification as by these that gender classify and carry with them the baggage of sexual stereotypes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, the constitution forbids Alabama to enact alimony statutes that classify on the basis of sex.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Stevens joined the Court's opinion have also filed concurring opinions. Mr. Justice Powell has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.text: Our opinion demonstrates that the state's compensatory and ameliorative purposes are as well served by a gender-neutral classification as by these that gender classify and carry with them the baggage of sexual stereotypes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, the constitution forbids Alabama to enact alimony statutes that classify on the basis of sex.

context.text: This case is here on appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Under Georgia law, the mother of an illegitimate child can sue for the wrongful death of that child.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: A father who has not legitimated a child however is precluded from maintaining a wrongful death action.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The question presented in this case is whether this statutory scheme violates the equal protection or Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment by denying a father of an illegitimate child who has not legitimated the child the right to sue for the child’s wrongful death.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Supreme Court of Georgia held that the Georgia law does not violate the constitution.

context.speaker: Jack B. Levitt

context.speaker: Samuel K. Rosen
context.text: In the Second Circuit, at least, in 1964 --

context.text: If the government wins, he wins.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: If the government loses, he gets his bite -- second bite at the output.

context.speaker: Samuel K. Rosen
context.text: If the government loses --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: If the government loses its case, the private plaintiff, by your answer to Justice White, isn't bound.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: He has his own day in Court and, if the government wins, he simply hitches his card under the government's victory.

context.speaker: Samuel K. Rosen
context.text: Well, as to the second part of your question, the -- I believe one of the purposes of the Securities and Exchange Commission is to act to protect the public.

context.text: This case is here by reason of the grant of a petition for writ of certiorari to review a judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

context.text: The respondent brought this stockholder’s class action against the petitioners in a Federal District Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The appellate court concluded and unfolding the Seventh Amendment preserves the right to jury trial only with respect to issues of fact, and once those issues have been fully and fairly adjudicated in a prior proceeding, nothing remains for trial, either with or without a jury. Because of an intercircuit conflict, we granted certiorari.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reason sent out in considerable detail in the Court's written opinion filed with clerk this morning, we affirmed the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Specifically, we hold that the use of so-called offensive collateral estoppel was permissible in this case and that it choose did not deprive the petitioners of any constitutional right.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, you're saying then that the -- there's a constitutional difference depending on whether they get his address in the warrant or not?

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: I'm not certain of that though.

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: I'm not certain that is -- I think the key thing is that the warrant --

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me that if you take that position you are really agreeing with Mr. Justice White that you want some kind of constitutional protection on knowing whether he's in the house or not, and that would be more like a search warrant.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And then you're going to say the time you go in to get the warrant, you got to be able to predict whether he'd be in the house at the time they get there or not.

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: Well, that's not what I'm after.

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: And I think --

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: So that the -- the narrow issue here is whether you need some kind of a warrant.

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: Yes, that's correct.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Heller -- Mr. Hellerstein, earlier in your argument you placed great stress on the -- using Coolidge versus New Hampshire, Justice Stewart's opinion as a starting point.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I take it Justice Harlan's concurring opinion wasn't necessary to make that a majority opinion?

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: Yes, and --

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: So that the -- the narrow issue here is whether you need some kind of a warrant.

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: Yes, that's correct.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Heller -- Mr. Hellerstein, earlier in your argument you placed great stress on the -- using Coolidge versus New Hampshire, Justice Stewart's opinion as a starting point.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I take it Justice Harlan's concurring opinion wasn't necessary to make that a majority opinion?

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: Yes, and --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And as I -- as I read his opinion, he starts out saying from the several opinions that have been filed in this case, it is apparent that the law of search and seizure is due for an overhauling, that's his -- then he goes on and says, I would begin this process of reevaluation by overruling Mapp against Ohio and Ker against California.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I take it Justice Harlan's concurring opinion wasn't necessary to make that a majority opinion?

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: Yes, and --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And as I -- as I read his opinion, he starts out saying from the several opinions that have been filed in this case, it is apparent that the law of search and seizure is due for an overhauling, that's his -- then he goes on and says, I would begin this process of reevaluation by overruling Mapp against Ohio and Ker against California.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, I take it if one were to follow Justice Harlan's views, which were necessary to make a majority, you wouldn't have much of a case.

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: I guess it would depend upon the composition of the Court at the current time, first of all, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William E. Hellerstein
context.text: I think that -- and I don't presume to speak for Mr. Justice Harlan that the considerations which he spoke to in those cases were his views of federalism in the role of the Fourth Amendment, and I know that you for one do share perhaps with respect to Mapp at least that view.

context.speaker: Peter L. Zimroth
context.text: So that I think it is fair to say that the police officers do not necessarily know in advance where to find the defendant.

context.speaker: Peter L. Zimroth
context.text: So those are the situations, at least that's the universe from which the police officers are going to have to go get a warrant since they're not going to know in advance where they're going to find him.

context.speaker: Peter L. Zimroth
context.text: There's another --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Isn't part -- isn't part of the montage or whatever you're going to call it, of argument analogous to Mr. Justice Stewart's comment in the earlier case that perhaps the most logical thing to do in connection with the Fifth Amendment is to ask the suspect, did you do it or not, and if not tell us where you were and so forth?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It's logical but the Fifth Amendment prohibits it, and there are lot of things in the Constitution that are prohibited by the -- that are prohibited that perhaps if we were to reexamine them today we wouldn't necessarily incorporate by the same token (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Peter L. Zimroth
context.text: Fourth Amendment by its terms talks about reasonableness.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: These appeals challenge the constitutionality of New York statutes that authorize police officers to enter a private residence without a warrant and with force, if necessary, to make a routine felony arrest.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The important constitutional question presented by this challenge has been expressly left open in a number of our prior opinions.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 841, Quern against Jordan and 1177, Scott against Illinois will each be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In Quern against Jordan which is a sequel to Edelman against Jordan which we decided five terms ago, the District Court for the Northern District of Illinois sitting in Chicago after our remand in the Edelman case ordered state officials to send to each member of the plaintiff, class, and notice informing them that he had been denied public assistance to which he was entitled.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The state appealed this decision to the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit and that Court sitting en banc reversed the District Court's order on the ground that that form of notice was barred by the Eleventh Amendment because it purported to decide that Illinois public funds should be used to satisfy the claims of the plaintiffs without the consent of the state.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Section 1983 does not explicitly and by clear language indicate on its face an intent to sweep away the traditional immunity of the states nor does it have a legislative history that focuses directly on the question of state liability or shows that Congress considered and decided to abrogate the Eleventh Amendment immunity of the states.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore conclude that Congress did not intend by the general language of Section 1983 to override that immunity.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Turning to the question whether the proposed notice of the Court of Appeals violates the Eleventh Amendment, we find that the notice is ancillary to prospective relief which is permissible under the decision in Ex parte Young and Edelman and not a retroactive award that requires payment of funds from the state treasury which we held was invalid under the Eleventh Amendment in Edelman.

context.text: In this case after receiving a report of a robbery of a closing store in Bourbonnais, Illinois.

context.text: The police stopped a suspect a getaway car in which petitioners were passengers.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They asserted neither a property nor a possessory interest in the automobile nor an interest in the property seized and the fact that they were legitimately on the premises in the sense that they were in the car with the permission of the owner is not determinative of whether they had a legitimate expectation of privacy in the particular areas of the automobile search.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Here petitioner simply made no showing that they had any such expectation of privacy in the glove compartment or area under the seat of the car in which they were merely passengers.

context.speaker: Walter C. Kurtz
context.text: Commissioners chose the master jury list, but then as I recall the clerk administers a system by which names are put in a pot and until recently a 10 year old child was brought in and drew out names at random.

context.speaker: Walter C. Kurtz
context.text: They went to serve the grand jury, they went to serve the criminal court juries, the civil court juries.

context.speaker: Walter C. Kurtz
context.text: But then completely outside of that is the judges' personal sort of selection procedure where he can reach out into the general population and choose anybody he or she wants as a foreman or a fore person of the grand jury.

context.text: Mr. Kurtz I am little bit concerned about the same point that Mr. Justice Blackmun raised with you earlier about the actual existence of a prima facie case.

context.text: The rationale of voiding the indictment in this case is supported by presumed prejudice, judicial integrity and maybe deterrence, but only maybe possibly deterrence.

context.speaker: Walter C. Kurtz
context.text: Now, this Court's decisions have never rested on that.

context.speaker: Walter C. Kurtz

context.text: Suppose Tennessee law allowed a charge to be instituted in -- even on a homicide case by information from the prosecutor and it appeared the prosecutors for -- ever since Tennessee had been member of the union had been white males appointed by the governor since you don't want to get into the election process, by appointed by the governor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It's Scott against Illinois which involves the question of whether or not the right to counsel is established in Argersinger against Hamlin seven years ago should be extended.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In Argersinger, we held that an indigent may not be imprisoned unless at his trial he was afforded the right of assistance of counsel at the State's expense.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The actual imprisonment line drawn in Argersinger has proved reasonably workable whether there's any extension we believe would create confusion and imposed unpredictable and necessarily substantial cause on 50 quite diverse states.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore hold that the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution require only that no indigent criminal defendant be sentenced to a term of imprisonment unless the State has afforded him the right to assistance of appointive counsel in his defense.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court of Illinois is accordingly affirmed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We’ll hear arguments first this morning in number 482, Robert K. Smith against the Daily Mail Publishing Company.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Hanley, you may proceed whenever you’re ready.

context.speaker: Howard L. Cardin
context.text: I do agree with that.

context.speaker: Howard L. Cardin
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Howard L. Cardin
context.text: As the dissent said, the progress--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Cardin, in agreeing with Mr. Justice Rehnquist, are you saying in effect that you would agree there would've been no search in the olden days, let's call it, my kids like to refer to it, when-- if it sat-- if a police officer had sat to the operator and broke down all the numbers that from a-- when a particular-- it said, “every time number so-and-so calls, I'd like to know who they're calling,” and he just sat there and wrote down the numbers they would call.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: There'd be no search there.

context.speaker: Howard L. Cardin
context.text: No, I'm not agreeing that there would be no search.

context.speaker: Howard L. Cardin
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Your answer is yes.

context.speaker: Howard L. Cardin
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Under Mr. Justice White's question, when the telephone company announced it, you'd be in the same situation on local calls as you would on long distance calls, wouldn't you?

context.speaker: Howard L. Cardin
context.text: I would agree with that.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And there's no intrusion.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: No.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But the vacation was not for purposes of seeing what accommodation could be made for in the operating room, but in the Southeastern Community College, wasn't it?

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And I heard by Mr. Justice Marshall's questions to go to her functioning in a hospital.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: Well from the record we the statement of the nursing director at Southeastern Community Hospital who indicated that she did not know any area that Mrs. Davis couldn't function given her present determination to continue her education.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: And indeed, Mrs. Davis at the present time obviously can't function in any capacity as a registered nurse and by going into the clinical program she attempts to advance her education so that she could function in areas as a registered nurse.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: The indication is, and again we have to see what hearing-impaired people are doing is that they are performing in the operating room, because they've received from their clinical instruction they've received training, they've received evaluation, and they received supervision.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: And this is an --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Are you answering my question?

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Now, Mr. Justice Marshall brought out the fact that she can perform with her hearing aid and so long as she is in the position to read lips.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In the operating room, the operating surgeons wear masks.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: The question of whether or not she can perform in the operating room may be premature that we first have to see how she would perform in the clinical setting.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: And in particular, one Senate Report states “Special attention must be paid to the needs of those individuals who through no fault of their own have not received adequate education.

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: These individuals, young adults and adults alike must be afforded the equal opportunity and access to higher educational services.”

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: The committee as we at the present time most of these avenues have not been available to people with handicaps.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Charmatz, on the question of the clinical program that Mr. Justice Blackmun was asking about, the District Court found that from the evidence presented at trial appears to be difficult and in fact dangerous for plaintiff to even attempt the clinical portion of the training program.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Do you challenge that finding?

context.speaker: Marc P. Charmatz
context.text: We think that the District Court asked the wrong questions.

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Quite different from its position below?

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans

context.speaker: Byron R. White

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans

context.speaker: Byron R. White

context.speaker: Doris Peterson

context.speaker: Doris Peterson

context.speaker: Doris Peterson
context.text: Though --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And you've also relied in your briefs on a letter from Deputy Attorney General White and -- and you've referred to I think a letter, a comment from Deputy Attorney General Katzenbach.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Did this bill have its genesis over a period of years?

context.speaker: Earl H. Nemser
context.text: And, if you look just at the paragraph above that, there's the venue problem they were talking about.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Well, then I must say I can -- I think it's true as Mr. Justice Stevens indicated, there is no one -- I don't think in this area there is one accounting method --

context.speaker: Byron R. White

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: But the point is, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But even if it conforms to entirely proper accounting practice and even if the accounting professional would say, this is the only way to do it, if the Commissioner can properly determine that it does not clearly reflect income, you win I would think?

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: That's absolutely the case and the reason we win in our view is because this doesn't meet the requirements of the regulations yes.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: I am sorry.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in Thor Power Tool against the Commissioner of Internal Revenue will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, this is a federal income tax case and it comes to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: That Court has had the United States' Tax Court before it decided the issues in favor of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and against the corporate taxpayer.

Thor Power Tool v. Commissioner of Inter.speaker: Justice Burger
Thor Power Tool v. Commissioner of Inter.case_name: Thor Power Tool v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue
Thor Power Tool v. Commissioner of Inter.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 16, 1979

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We hold that the Commissioner did not abuse his discretion when he ruled that the inventory write-down effectuated by the taxpayer did not reflect income clearly for income tax purposes.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And also that he did not abuse his discretion when he disallowed in part the taxpayer's addition to its bad debt reserve.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In reaching these conclusions we emphasize that what may be appropriate for accounting purposes does not necessarily govern for income tax purposes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 77-1645, Transamerica Mortgage Advisors against Lewis will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here on a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 was enacted to deal with abuses that Congress had found to exist in the investment advisers industry.

Transamerica Mortgage Advisors, Inc. v..speaker: Justice Stewart

Transamerica Mortgage Advisors, Inc. v..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - NOVEMBER 13, 1979

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In view of these express provisions for enforcing the duties imposed, we think it is highly improbable that Congress absentmindedly forgot to mention and intended private action.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons I have outlined, all of which are discussed in considerably greater detail in the written opinion of the Court filed this morning we hold that there exist a limited private remedy under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 to void an investment adviser's contract but that the Act confers no other private causes of action, legal or equitable.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed in part and reversed in part and the case is remanded to that court for further proceedings consistent with the written opinion of this Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell while joining the opinion of the Court has filed a concurring statement.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion which Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Stevens have joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: M. Carr Ferguson
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

context.speaker: M. Carr Ferguson
context.text: I’m afraid our differences are more basic than I had originally anticipated from reading the briefs.

context.speaker: M. Carr Ferguson
context.text: The Government simply does not accept the basic premise that there are three pots or three conduits or three shells, whatever they are.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What would you say Mr. Ferguson about Justice White’s hypothetical case, if the entire state you were given to the University of California or some totally recognizable tax entity that was exempt, income on these earnings during the period of probate proceedings?

context.speaker: M. Carr Ferguson
context.text: Sir I would have to say that first of all, the estate is nonetheless a tax payer, a private tax payer under the provisions of the code as it would be in any other case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You mean until distribution, the entity takes on the cloak of the decedent and not the cloak of the legatee?

United California Bank v. United States.speaker: Justice Burger
United California Bank v. United States.case_name: United California Bank v. United States
United California Bank v. United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 04, 1978

context.speaker: M. Carr Ferguson
context.text: The special 691 (c) deduction I think can be explained as an off set in the nature of the credit to make sure that items which were taxable were subject to the estate tax are not again subject to an income tax which might duplicate and indeed exceed the principle amount of the item itself.

context.speaker: M. Carr Ferguson
context.text: There are special considerations there which I think just are not present in any of the so-called ordinary deductions described in the tax.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Ferguson earlier I said you seemed to answer the same question two different ways and I realized that in this exchanges here a word here or there can make the difference and let me try again, even if there is an over simplification.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Taking Mr. Justice White’s hypothetical case, Mr. Disney left everything, his entire estate after the expenses with the administration to this tax exempt entity charitable.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Do I understand you to concede no income tax during the pendency of the probate proceeding, no income tax after the date of death, is that right?

context.speaker: M. Carr Ferguson
context.text: Assuming, Your Honor if I may add one more fact I can agree with you, assuming that the gross income of the estate could be off set by a deduction under 642 (c) which met the various requirements of that deduction section I would agree.

context.speaker: Richard A. Allen
context.text: In fact it reflects a rather startling proposition of law that few regulatory agencies could operate under.

context.speaker: Richard A. Allen
context.text: In effect, it would mean that anytime a statute requires agency authorization for an action, such as a certificate to operate an airline or license to sell alcoholic beverages, a person who was charged with failing to obtain that authorization would have a defense, a legal defense that if he had applied to the agency at some previous and proper time, the agency probably would have given him the authority.

context.speaker: Richard A. Allen
context.text: In essence that’s what respondents’ position boils down to.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Do you think that might put a premium on having some lawyers go around pursing Mr. Justice Marshall’s suggestion and get affidavits from the former members of the Commission as some lawyers do going around the jurors --

context.speaker: Richard A. Allen
context.text: It would put a tremendous premium on such activity Your Honor.

context.speaker: Richard A. Allen
context.text: Now respondent is trying to buttress this argument by arguing that Haring’s failure to apply for an abandonment application was “good faith.”

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: -- Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We’ll hear arguments first this morning in United States against Batchelder.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Levander, you may proceed whenever you’re ready.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens will announce the judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 1309, United States against Caceres.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: This case presents the question whether evidence obtained in violation of Internal Revenue Service regulations may be admitted at the criminal trial of a taxpayer accused of bribing an Internal Revenue Service agent.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Internal Revenue Service manual contains detailed procedures that must be followed before conversations between an agent and a taxpayer may be recorded electronically without the taxpayer's knowledge.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We reject respondent's contention that exclusion is always an appropriate remedy whenever evidence is obtained in violation of a valid regulation.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And further hold that the circumstances involved in this case do not justify the suppression remedy.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We therefore reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Brennan has joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But here before they advance the money, they cant go out, make a title research like any other lender can.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Why shouldnt they have that obligation?

context.speaker: Stephen R. Barnett
context.text: Well because Congress has not said so for one thing, the rule was laid down by this Court and the tax lien area has been followed by the Courts of Appeals was unanimously followed by the --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But you just told Mr. Justice Rehnquist, you are asking us to extend that rule --

context.speaker: Stephen R. Barnett
context.text: I'm asking this Court to extend this since this Court has not done so but the Courts of Appeals found no difficulty at all in concluding that the reasons this Court had given for the rule and the tax lien contacts were equally applicable to contractual liens.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, I suggest you they are not equally applicable because in one case the government can check title and in the other case it cant.

context.text: At issue here is whether state or federal law should be used to establish a relative priority of private items, private liens and federal contractual liens.

United States v. Kimbell Foods, Inc..speaker: Justice Burger
United States v. Kimbell Foods, Inc..case_name: United States v. Kimbell Foods, Inc.
United States v. Kimbell Foods, Inc..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 02, 1979

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, we adopt the state commercial law as the appropriate federal rule of decision, leaving Congress free to establish uniform priority rules through legislation.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Because the Court of Appeals in Number 1359 found that the Texas law gave the private lien preference over the federal lien, we affirm that judgment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We remand 16044 for the Court to determine whether the private or federal lien involved in that case is superior under Georgia law.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: He said there'd be a different case because there might be prejudice.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: At least that's what I understood him to say.

context.speaker: Kenneth M. Mogill
context.text: There are obviously cases that --

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think Mr. Justice White's example is even farther removed than that one.

context.speaker: Kenneth M. Mogill
context.text: I think --

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: So, I may be right that the court would rule that way, probably not the argument.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The opinion in 77-1254, Vance, Secretary of State versus Bradley will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Section 632 of the Foreign Service Act of 1946 requires that all employees subject to the Foreign Service Retirement System retire at age 60.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: In contrast, at the time the suit was brought, government employee is subject to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability System, were not required to retire until age 70.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: A three-judge court held that this difference in retirement ages discriminated against foreign service personnel and that the discrimination was an invidious one that violated the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We noted probable jurisdiction and we reversed that judgment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Our reasons are elaborated in the opinion that has been filed with the clerk.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We noted probable jurisdiction and we reversed that judgment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Our reasons are elaborated in the opinion that has been filed with the clerk.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.speaker: Justice Burger
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.case_name: Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 02, 1978

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: Congress heard other witnesses on the other hand who felt that the option of partial jurisdiction was such a good idea that it should be expressly spelled out in the statute.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: In 1968, with this knowledge, Congress rejected the Yakima's demand for unilateral retrocession, ended the argument over partial jurisdiction by expressly authorizing it, and confirmed preexisting assumptions of jurisdiction of which Washington's had been pivotal during the debate leading up to those 1968 amendments to Public Law 280.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: General Gorton, let me take you back a few steps.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Do I understand from your answer to Mr. Justice Rehnquist that a constitutional amendment in the State of Washington must first go through a constitutional convention called by the legislature and then subject to a vote of the people.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: No, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Which is it that's -- is it one or the other?

Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.speaker: Justice Burger
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.case_name: Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 02, 1978

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: The legislature may also call for a constitutional convention, which if it is approved by the people then meets, then presumably can write an entirely new constitution.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Then they've delegated the power to the convention?

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: Yes, but the actions of that Convention would have to be approved by the people.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I understood you -- I thought you said to Mr. Justice Rehnquist that even after the convention drafts the amendment, the people must pass on it.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: That is true.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: If a constitutional convention is called into being in the State of Washington, its actions if any would be subject to the approval by the people.

Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.speaker: Justice Stevens
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.case_name: Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 02, 1978

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: Or as we suggest in our brief, it may mean where there are only statutes, not constitutional provisions, and in the view of the state court, it is nevertheless necessary to remove that obstacle by popular referendum.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: It was so suggested by a committee counsel in the hearings and that is we suggest the only reason why the words “where necessary” were introduced.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: To read it otherwise is to make Section 6 wholly surplusage and to read out the proviso which says, “Such jurisdiction shall not obtain until and unless the appropriate amendment has been made.”

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Claiborne, I'm not sure that completely answers Justice Rehnquist's question because both in the proviso and in the introductory portion of 6 is a reference to the people amending the constitution or statute as the case may be.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In both cases, the word people would seem to encompass acts by the legislature.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you agree or disagree with that?

Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.speaker: Justice Stevens
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.case_name: Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 02, 1978

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: One last word, if I may.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: The result which we suggest is rightly reached in this case does conform with the congressional policy in 1968 to compel the parties, the tribe and the state to reach accommodations at arms length and therefore to reduce the friction and the inefficiency of a law enforcement system where the parties are at odds.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: The parties should now return to the bargaining table as free agents and work out on accommodations.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Claiborne, before you sit down, I'd like to ask you one further question on the jurisdictional problem that Justice White identified.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Is it not correct that if we accept your theory as opposed to the theory of the Court of Appeals, that will invalidate the assumption of jurisdiction with respect to the nine tribes who consented to a full acceptance of jurisdiction, whereas the rationale of the Ninth Circuit would not?

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: Mr. Justice Stevens, it is certainly correct that our submission would, though perhaps not in this case, but the logic of our submission would invalidate those assumptions with respect to tribes between 1957 and 1963 who took on full jurisdiction.

Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.speaker: Justice Burger
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.case_name: Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 16, 1979

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 388, Washington State against Confederated Bands and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here on a direct appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We are called upon in this case to resolve a dispute between the State of Washington and the Yakima Indian Nation over the validity of the state's exercise of jurisdiction on the Yakima Reservation.

Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.speaker: Justice Stewart
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.case_name: Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation
Washington v. Confederated Bands and Tri.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 16, 1979

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Second, it contends that Public Law 280 does not authorize any state to extend only partial jurisdiction over an Indian reservation.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Finally, it asserts that Chapter 36 even if authorized by Public Law 280 violates the Fourteenth Amendment of the constitution as the Court of Appeals held.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in detail in the Court's necessarily discursive written opinion, we reject all of these claims and reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion which Mr. Justice Brennan has joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Let me put the question this way.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Would your case be any different if some of the claimants were from Nigeria or from China?

context.speaker: Edson Smith
context.text: Well, according to the-- that argument, if they were from Nigeria or China and they were discriminated against as between them and White persons, the -- that would make the section unconstitutional, but what I'm saying is it's equally unconstitutional where it's simply discrimination of this sort between an Indian and a White person.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Smith, following up on Justice Blackmun's point, as I understand it, the record does not tell us the race of your individual clients.

context.speaker: Edson Smith
context.text: That's fair.

context.speaker: Edson Smith
context.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Veeder
context.text: I used 194 and relied upon it.

context.speaker: William H. Veeder
context.text: There's no question about it, but I do say that you cannot extract 1-- 25 USC 194 from this lawsuit.

context.speaker: William H. Veeder
context.text: You can't take it out of the context of what we referred in the history of it and I don't think we should do that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Is it under state law or federal law that you responded to Mr. Justice White, if I understood you, that when the evidence is evenly balanced, the plaintiff prevails?

context.speaker: William H. Veeder
context.text: If we're in possession, yes.

context.speaker: William H. Veeder
context.text: I think so.

context.speaker: Sara S. Beale
context.text: Well, I think it was not only that there might be a disadvantage but that there was a very important press to protecting the tribal land so that they wouldn't be lost in a questionable case.

context.speaker: Sara S. Beale
context.text: Now, granted the United States as a representative of the tribe would be more familiar with Court rules and Court procedures and would have more resources, but I don't think that there should be a rule that would cut against or discourage the United States from helping out an Indian tribe or a single Indian from enforcing his rights, and I think that the purpose of protecting Indian lands is the same.

context.speaker: Sara S. Beale
context.text: So that, the fact that the United States comes in and if the real party in interest is someone entitled to invoke Section 194 to protect those Indian interests that it should not make a difference that the government has more resources or is more familiar with Courtroom procedures.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mrs. Beale, following up on Justice Stevens' question, is there any precise date that can be assigned to the time when the United States began to sue on behalf of Indian awards for title to land?

context.speaker: Sara S. Beale
context.text: That's a new suggested question.

context.speaker: Sara S. Beale
context.text: There are some very early cases.

Wolston v. Reader's Digest Association,.speaker: Justice Burger
Wolston v. Reader's Digest Association,.case_name: Wolston v. Reader's Digest Association, Inc.
Wolston v. Reader's Digest Association,.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 17, 1979

context.speaker: John J. Buckley, Jr.
context.text: And this conduct occurred in the context of a major controversy over Soviet espionage.

context.speaker: John J. Buckley, Jr.
context.text: Let me say there's no contention here that Wolston was the prime actor in the entire controversy, but he was at least a supporting actor who was starring in his own subplot with a script he largely authored by his own contempt.

context.speaker: John J. Buckley, Jr.
context.text: And therefore became part of the larger drama.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now what if having been convicted either by government employee going home from work and resist arrest or Mr. Justice White's hypothetical case and first there's a conviction for a contempt or whatever.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You say that automatically makes him a public figure?

context.speaker: John J. Buckley, Jr.
context.text: If one engages in criminal conduct, I think it does.

Wolston v. Reader's Digest Association,.speaker: Justice White
Wolston v. Reader's Digest Association,.case_name: Wolston v. Reader's Digest Association, Inc.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well say the man says you --

context.speaker: Sidney Dickstein
context.text: Because there are.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Say the man says the mental element could be satisfied if there are obvious reasons to doubt the veracity of the informant or the accuracy of his report.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now, what -- how did you, Mr. Justice Stevens asked you how did you satisfy that burden of proof.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What obvious reasons were there for the defendant to doubt the accuracy of his information objectively?

context.speaker: Sidney Dickstein
context.text: Objectively.
